author: {'steamid': '76561198813291076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 247, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1711252935}
review:
I started on EQ from the very first. Loved it then, and love it now. Yes the game experience has changed, but I think if you find good players to group with you can still have a good time. After all its the grouping that makes this game.

On the tech side. I have just installed Steam on my fully patched Fedora 35 with an Nvidia card and the vendor's drivers installed. I set my settings to use the experimental Proton layer, and while it did install 32 bit packages, it worked. And EQ to my surprise and delight came up and worked! 

There are a couple of small tricks though:
1) To get the mouse mapping to line up with the buttons vertically I had to either go full screen, <ALT><ENTER>, or maximize your window. Notice that full screen and maxed window both worked.
2) There were the occasional moments when I needed to click twice on something to get it to work, but that didn't really bother me. 
To me these were such small nit picks that I feel I can say "it just worked". YMMV.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087531803', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 58, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1711224907}
review:
Hallo,

nach meinen ersten Eindrücken kann ich das Spiel nur absolut jedem Empfehlen der MMOs mag. 
Everquest ist ja sozusagen einer der Urväter, aber es ist immer noch da und wird aktiv gespielt! Ich war auf mehreren Servern und auf jedem sind in den Anfänger gebieten Spieler unterwegs.

Das Spiel wird eben Hauptsächlich über den eigenen Launcher gespielt und nicht über Steam.

Das Spiel ist ja von 1999 und erhält immer noch stetig Updates und Erweiterungen! Aktuell bei Nr. 30 meine ich.

Wenn man mal etwas anderes wie die heutigen Games erleben möchte und sich auf ein Abenteuer einlassen kann, ohne sofort innerhalb von wenig Aufwand viel erreicht zu haben, ist das hier für jeden einen Versuch wert!

Ebenso Everquest 2.


MfG

author: {'steamid': '76561198030147332', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1704166254}
review:
Paying for one month signs you up for recurring billing and it is not refundable. I only wanted to play around for a few hours on classic servers for a little nostalgia, and haven't touched the game in the two months since and I'm out $48.  

You cannot play classic on F2P, and you can't get a refund when they trick you into recurring payments.  Lesson learned, Daybreak, lesson learned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055215328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 11138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11138, 'last_played': 1702073165}
review: A lot of people play this game thinking it is going to be like it was in the past.  Fact is, no game will ever be like this was in the past.  Everquest was always ahead of its time and releasing new updated content for YEARS literally just releasing their new expansion in December.  The game is not super easy and after about lvl 80 to 85 it starts to really get group reliant unless you are patient.  My hours on steam do not reflect my true game play time.  I wish i knew how many actual hours i put into this game being a raider for 10+ years and being one of the top in my class server wide for a few of those years.  This will forever and always be one of those games i will never not return back to.  If Mischief server ever becomes a FTP server, you better believe i will be back playing near full time again haha.

review:
Epoch defining classic. If you have memories of this game from 1999-2001 and wish to relive it - you *might* prefer project 1999 vs live EQ. Live is MUCH faster, more modern, updated, vastly more content, QoL improvements, runs smoother etc.. however it is not classic EQ. If you want the pain; try p1999.

EDIT: Try Project Quarm or P1999

review: Old but great memories that allow you to relive. If you don't need your hand held & like a challenge also researching quests and steps, this game is for you! With the added adventure of the huge world, great stories built within. Minor achievements by getting keys to areas to explore or working towards your epic's. Nothing will recreate the 90's experience but its still very enjoyable for people with extra time and seeking adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037243294', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4021, 'last_played': 1440644531}
review:
This is my favorite game of all time (don't usually play via Steam).  For anyone new to the game or looking to satisfy their nostalgia, a new Time-Locked Progression (TLP) server is usually announced/released around May each year.  These servers usually start at the original game and release expansions based on time, voting, or some other criteria (announced each year).  TLP's are the easiest way to get introduced into the 24+ years of content that has been added to the game.  It's much easier to learn the game starting at level 1 where the lower level zones are packed with people, pickup groups are likely, and people are more receptive to new players.  TLP's are also typically more reasonable for raiding time required given people with busy schedules and families.

I think that in order to really enjoy the later expansions after the first ~6 or so (and there are like 30 now), you really need to seek out a dedicated guild or group of friends to play with.  Everquest has had a lot of great quality of life features added over the years, but especially in the early days its not the type of game to hold your hand.  Everything is much more rewarding when you have to really earn it, when you have to rely on other players, and things aren't just handed to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076333546', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1700951061}
review:
I created an account, but accidentally had a type-o when entering my email address.
I could not change my email address, because the type-o email needed to be verified first. (Goodbye the account name I wanted)
I made a new account, and when I went to play the game, the scaling of my desktop (I have it at 150% because I am on a 15" laptop) Was too big to fit the game screen, so I could not see a large portion of the game screen, so I changed the scaling, and when I went back to the game, my mouse cursor was located in a totally different location on the application, than what it appeared on my screen, not to mention that the game is nearly unplayable at this scaling unless I want to sit 3" from my laptop screen.

Don't even bother installing this crap, if the company doesn't care enough to make the game presentable, or have any way of fixing a simple email error during account creation (I wonder how many dead accounts exist just because someone typed in their email wrong during creation?) they do not deserve your support.

I normally have a lot of patience with games, I have played Old School Runescape for nearly 3k hours, but if there are this many difficulties and headaches before you even get to make a character, then absolutely fuck spending any money on this company.

Back to Old School Runescape / Classic/Retail WoW / Elder Scrolls online....literally any other mmo I guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977033265', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2625, 'last_played': 1699482468}
review:
Cool, old-school mmorpg. 
I'd recommend, if it didn't paywall your progression. Despite the big free-to-play tag, the game is very much pay-to-win. 
People who sub to the game get their skill point limit removed or lifted, which is just one of the worst things you could do. 
Non-ethical. Can't recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974183670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 14168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8409, 'last_played': 1708825143}
review: After Ultima Online this was THE GAME to play back in the day. It has gone through so much in 50 years,but still maintains its appeal to the hardcore MMORPG player. It has some of the best original sound effects ever made with uncompromising reverb and bass. It has more to do now than most MMO's will ever have. This is a game for a specific audience and meets those needs. It's not for everyone,but its definitely one of my all time best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046228036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 44714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24480, 'last_played': 1703004254}
review: Got back into the game after a LONG break.  It's a bit overwhelming to get started but once you do the game is extremely easy.   Tutorial holds your hand once you get rolling.  The key is take it slow and patience.  When I finally got out of the tutorial players just handed me items, buffed me and away I went.  You can Hire AI's to play with you , Much better with a healer AI or Tank.  One of my characters is in a guild and the guild is active with really nice people.  I hated the map the game came with BUT you can download a map and VIOLA> it even gives you a trail  to follow to get to your destination.  Once out of the tutorial I stopped doing the quests and started just killing mobs which made it more enjoyable. The questing is terrible. You have to give the game a chance to get going. Cannot play for a few minutes to get a good Idea of how the game is. It is NOT the EQ game I remember from 1999 but still fun to play especially with friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054546457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1698226567}
review:
I played Everquest Online Adventures for over a year back on the Playstation 2, about 20 years ago, and I hoped to replicate my positive experiences here.
This is nowhere near the quality of that game. 

The new player experience is absolutely terrible.  I have 2 hours played now... still trying to figure out the UI and how to drag spells from my spellbook to my Hotbar.

I haven't made it out of the starting area, or done any quests, or killed more than the first mob in the tutorial but I can already tell this is going to be an experience... Which would all be fine.  I can deal with that. After all this is an MMO, and an old one at that.

What I can't deal with the constant reminders that I should really look at some exciting deals and microtransactions, buy a subscription, and upgrade to premium. More than that: They want to charge MORE than Final Fantasy 14 does for it's sub... and that's an actual AAA quality game.  

For me the lack of quality, the terrible intro experience, and the predatory monetization are my takeaways from my time here, and I have no interest in even trying to proceed further... which is a shame because I had really high hopes for this game.  

24 years and they haven't got the first hour of the New Player experience figured out.  I understand that Everquest has a solid small group of very devoted players that keeps the game afloat, and it's a shame they haven't put the same effort into retaining new players and expanding on that as they have into their predatory microtransactions.

1/10, would not recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963769406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1355990400}
review:
I played classic through to Luclin, at which point I didn't recognise the game anymore. If you enjoyed the experience prior to that expansion, Project 1999 might scratch the itch; otherwise, I have nothing to say. I don't like this game anymore; there's no place for you unless you pay to boost your character to godly levels. I can't keep track of all the new stuff they've added over the decades, there's nobody to talk to or group with, and the few folks you do run into are mute at best and unfriendly at worst; what's the point of an MMO if you play it alone?

Everquest died a long time ago. Whatever this is, I'm not interested.

review:
This may only show 14hrs on my steam account, but I have thousands of hours on this game. I first thought EverQuest and not a fun game and something that was outdated and World of Warcraft was superior and the king of all MMOs.  

I was wrong, that title at least now in my opinion really does belong to EQ - Amazing lore, amazing fantasy settings. You can play this game for hours. I really do recommend you try one of the TLP servers. Talk to people get into a guild try some raiding. This game is legit fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075567524', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 256661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 17609, 'playtime_at_review': 63634, 'last_played': 1711245623}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025674822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1697228180}
review:
The community is really hostile to new players. I asked a simple question in new player chat and was insulted over and over rather than being helped out. They acted like I punched their grandma. The game doesn't hold your hand at all and it's easy to miss small but vital details that are required to function in this mess of an ancient mmo. 

I saw a tutorial button and thought to myself "I should do that" and clicked it. Nothing happened so I clicked it again, once or twice. "Ok then..." I create a character and enter the world which takes me directly into the city where I spend the first 10-20 minutes un-fucking the UI. Getting my bearings, I made my way to the first quest which was kill four spiders and talk to npc. Seems easy enough only after killing the enemies, the npc would cycle the quest start text and not the completion text. Apparently, clicking the tutorial button at character creation decides if you do the tutorial, which makes perfect sense. Only, there's zero notification if the button is on or off or if you've missed it ect. So not only was a large vital part of the game simply bypassed with no warning, the game also did nothing to hint at the correct action to take. The only information you get is to type "hail" in chat. 

Turns out after scouring the options, you HAVE to press H to hail and not type it as instructed. This is hilarious to those who have been around and so i received nothing short of harassment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129488584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 4867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1393, 'last_played': 1697534397}
review:
Ultimately it /was/ a good game, 2 decades ago, that is trying to be monetized like its a modern AAA game, complete with pricing equal to or greater than games released this year. Look at the graphics and ask yourself if that's worth a full $15/month, you /can/ play it free, with severely limited functionality, server selection, and constant popups telling you to pay for it. 

Is a game that came out in *1999* worth paying full price for, and I'm gonna say no. Not just the graphics, but the QoL, functionality, engine, everything. It's a shame because I played this as a child and remembered it being.. far better than this

author: {'steamid': '76561198042369398', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3650, 'last_played': 1598205579}
review:
As much as this pains me, i cant recommend this game for new players, or people who are just looking for a game to mess around in. I recently started putting hours in to Everquest again, ive been off and on playing EQ since 2001, and with no suprise at all there are still some good people around but there are still a lot of garbage people around. Good luck getting any group at all at any level, unless u can pay for power levels. This doesnt just effect only the main servers but the TLP (time locked progression) servers as well. I spent alot of time playing when the Mischief server came out, i loved the randomized loot rules, and had plenty of group invites playing a shaman even got in to a raid guild and was raiding multiple times a week. Then the garbage time comes around, The Shadows of Luclin is unlocked and the "WTS Powerlevel..." spam starts. Group invites become few and far between, the guild starts to fall apart when main people start leaving. I spent so many hours, a lvl 60 raid geared shaman, just looking for some AA (alternate ability *i fucking hate and love these at the same time*) with no luck at all.  

So i took a break i come back and play on Firiona vie server (yet another mistake), I thought ill go find some gear on the bazaar and saw the absurd prices and said ok nvm ill see if i can get some stuff from old world raid content. Being a free trade/RP server (pretty much everything is tradeable) nothing is really ever up you kinda have to camp it or get really luck for certain things. So that all went out the window, and i was left with farming trash, getting crafting mats i knew i could sell to players. Once i amassed a hoard of goodies to throw at people to attempt to make some plat for my and an alt, i was informed by the game that i can not sell any items or setup a barter to buy any items in the bazaar as a free to play player, but i can still buy items from players selling items. Which ok sure why not i thought, fine ill check out how much a krono (currency item for game time) is..... 10+ million platinum. Which you cant sell items to player so unless u wanna sit in chat channels spamming that your selling things you'll need to either A) spend $$$ to get a subscription or B) sell everything to a vendor. So i did some testing, being someone who really wasnt in the know on where to farm for money, i went to different zones from higher level to lower level and tested money/hour. The best i could manage before to  defeat sunk in was about 12k for several hours for farming lower level content for gems/spells drops since they sold the best to vendors. The thing that killed me was respawn time, or players in the zone mass pulling to powerlevel alts or people who paid them $$$ or kronos.
 
These ware the factors that cause me to stop enjoying everquest, the remnants of the "community" at  the lower levels, no ones grouping due to no new people, or the amount of power leveling. The choke hold that free to play game companies put in games to get you to pay them, such as but not limited to  not being able to wear (or receive stats from) gear tagged prestige once our subscription ends, not being able to sell items in the only place to really make in game money in a timely manner, not being able to setup a barter character to buy specific things at the price you set, and the tens of thousands of AAs which isnt as bad now thanks to the autogrant system  just giving them to you as long as you have a subscription or you can farm the exp for 1k points max to grind and use. Honestly Project 99 has a much better feel for me, even with so few people online when i get on i can still on most days get a group and get things done. 

Save your drive space and move along.

author: {'steamid': '76561198405234657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 171152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164757, 'last_played': 1707590538}
review:
So starting with the only pros... its still an alive game, and each new time-locked server brings loads of population, thats roughly where it ends though. Lag on raids (bristlebane) at the worse is multiple seconds from cast, to damage/healing numbers showing up on chat. Each year there is a race starting in Janurary-March after expansion launch of who can finish all the raids in the fastest time, beyond march there are no content updates and patches are 1x/month. There is, an albeit, a dated tradeskill grind system, slayer achievements, older content etc to do but the game punishes any alternate characters you make.
There's a large botting problem too, every time locked server and on most live servers you will see many people in general looking to sell their stuff for krono (membership token), which then gets reselled on 3rd party sites for money to the player that owned those kronos. These people can play 10, 15, possibly more accounts, and not get banned unless they are actually afk and dont respond to private messages from GMs. The same can similarly be applied to chat spammers.
If you do not care for these things, the game can be pretty good but I wouldnt find myself recommending EQ to anybody that wants to put in more serious time into a new game as there is little payoff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198267515320', 'num_games_owned': 385, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 2546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1694892599}
review:
Good old game! From the good old SOE times, when SWG was live. Graphics are a bit outdates for today's times, but overall it is a great and vast game, with tons of stuff to do and also quite complex in many ways, with several nice and unique features. It is fun to hop on with friends and play for a while. 

But you also need to read a lot, since there is no voice in the game, which might make it difficult for some. For me personally, being from an older generation of players, it is not much of an issue. I am used to read and write a lot... Heck, my first game was a text based adventure on MS DOS. :D 

Especially given that it is free, there is not much wrong with trying it and having some fun. Subscription prices are reasonable, as they are for all the games. Just give it a try and see for yourself, I'd say.

review:
do NOT play the steam or official retail version, it's a dead game full of multiboxers and antisocial minmaxers that degenerated over the years into a sad clone of wow. 95% of the game is dead content, most of the playerbase runs 2-6 accounts and refuses to interact with each other, you're bombarded with superfluous mechanics they added over the years that stopped being useful in like 2013, it's not worth a subscription

i know i'm gonna get hate from brain damaged boomers for this but if you want to try to the authentic eq experience as a newcomer look up Project1999 and join the discord for instructions on how to install

author: {'steamid': '76561198051497554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1665977629}
review:
EverQuest, a groundbreaking MMORPG developed by Sony Online Entertainment (now Daybreak Game Company), stands as a testament to the enduring legacy of online gaming. With its vast, immersive world, intricate gameplay mechanics, and strong sense of community, EverQuest has left an indelible mark on the genre, captivating players for decades.

Immersive World and Exploration: 4.8/5

EverQuest's expansive and intricately designed world is a true marvel. From the bustling cities to the treacherous dungeons, every corner of Norrath is teeming with lore, secrets, and stories waiting to be uncovered. The game's commitment to immersive storytelling and diverse environments invites players to embark on a journey of exploration, sparking a sense of wonder that few other games can replicate.

Challenging Gameplay and Mechanics: 4.7/5

Unlike many contemporary MMORPGs, EverQuest embraced challenge and depth in its gameplay mechanics. The intricate class system, complete with unique abilities and strengths, demands strategic thinking and collaboration. The game's combat, which relies on strategy and teamwork, encourages players to form groups and develop synergistic tactics to conquer tough adversaries. The sense of accomplishment gained from overcoming formidable challenges is truly gratifying.

Rich Community and Social Interaction: 4.9/5

EverQuest's strong sense of community has fostered friendships and memories that have lasted for years. Players are encouraged to work together, forming lasting bonds while tackling quests, dungeons, and raids. The necessity of cooperation and communication has led to the formation of guilds and alliances, contributing to the game's vibrant and closely-knit player base.

Evolving Content and Expansions: 4.6/5

EverQuest's enduring appeal can be attributed to its continuous commitment to evolving content. Regular updates and expansions have introduced new lands, quests, challenges, and gameplay mechanics, ensuring that the world of Norrath remains fresh and engaging. This dedication to keeping the game alive and evolving showcases the developers' understanding of their player base's desires.

Visuals and Sound: 4.4/5

While the game's graphics have evolved over the years, they've always been tied to the technology of their time. The visual charm of EverQuest lies in its artistic design, capturing the essence of a high fantasy world. The music and sound effects complement the atmosphere, immersing players further into the rich tapestry of Norrath.

Conclusion: 4.7/5

EverQuest is a testament to the power of immersive world-building, challenging gameplay, and a dedicated community. Its enduring legacy is a testament to its timeless appeal, capturing the hearts of players through the years. Whether you're a veteran player nostalgic for the early days or a newcomer seeking a taste of classic MMORPG magic, EverQuest offers a rich and captivating experience that's well worth the journey into the realm of Norrath.

author: {'steamid': '76561198266927672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1691985838}
review: If you're like me and have trouble reading screens at times, I wouldn't bother even downloading this game. I played Champions Of Norrath on PS2 for probably 2 decades now, and saw this the other day. Thought since it's in the Norrath realm, I might enjoy it even though I don't really like playing multi-player games much. I couldn't even get past the tutorial due to the small text size and annoying amount of windows used in game. Not being able to read the text made it extremely difficult to know what I was supposed to do or where things went. And the amount of windows made it hard to know what I was supposed to be looking at. Just way to much stuff on the screen for me to even begin to enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198306407762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1689953332}
review:
See 1,2 hours of gameplay on my account? It is 1,2 hours of attempts to log in.
First, I get an error NBE-1013 every time I am trying to log in. 
I search for the error code. It says "If you've reached this error message through the LaunchPad, please note that this is a temporary issue related to Daybreak product maintenance. Please check the forums or news section of your respective game for related notifications".
Checking the forums. Nothing seems out of ordinary.
Trying to access support page.
There are no instructions to such situations.
Trying to message support.
Didn't make it, because subjects i can make letters to support about, are limited to returning purchases, deleting accounts and unbanning.
My first time with everquest. Thanks a lot, hope to never come back. 1/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198052313814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 37175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12724, 'last_played': 1697149733}
review:
Damals, muss so um die 2000 rum gewesen sein, habe ich ein wenig dieses MMO gespielt. Vielleicht für 2-3 Monate. Dann habe ich es jedoch aus den Augen verloren. Es kam WoW, Everquest 2, Rift, TESO, FF14 und noch diverse andere MMOs und Online-Spiele, die ich seit dem gespielt habe. 
Vor kurzem entdeckte ich Everquest hier auf Steam - und obwohl ich gerade FF14 eine monatliche Spielzeit am laufen hatte, reizte es mich, mal hineinzuschnuppern.
Was soll ich sagen: es hat mich von Anfang an begeistert. Vor allem das Spielen auf einem TLP (Time Locked Progression)-Server ist fasnierend. Das sind Server, die mit Everquest Vanilla starten und alle paar Wochen eine der 29 Erweiterungen als Update erhalten. Man durchläuft also die Everquest-Geschichte von Anfang an und hat vor allem am Anfang das Original-Spielerlebnis nahezu wieder.
Und das hat es in sich. Besonders durch die Eigenheit der Mobs, sich gegenseitig im Kampf zu unterstützen, kommt es oft zu spannenden Situationen. Da flieht ein Mob aus dem Kampf und wenn er an Freunden vorbei kommt, schließen diese sich dem Kampf an - in manchen Dungeons kommt es daher oft zu  kritischen Situationen (sprich Wipes). Auch lassen sich Mobs mit Aggro nicht so einfach abschütteln - da muss man schon mal durch die ganze Zone rennen, und wehe, man ist nicht schnell genug, dann machen einen die Verfolger fertig.
Ja, und das schmerzt - 10% Exp Abzug zum nächsten Level ca. gehen verloren - und man kann sogar im Level zurückgestuft werden.
Das Spiel ist komplex, knifflig, auf charmante Art sperrig. Wer Wert auf moderne Grafik legt, ist hier allerdings komplett falsch - an so manchem Gebilde (egal ob Monster, Haus oder Held) kann man die Polygon-Eckpunkte sehen und es gibt keine Ahs und Ohs wegen toller Grafik. Dafür benötigt das Game allerdings auch weniger Leistung - was mir entgegen kommt.
Ist es P2W? Nun ja... fürs erste sinnvoll ist sicherlich eine monatliche Spielzeit - man kann sehr gut reinschnuppern im F2P - aber die TLP-Server sowie das weitere Gameplay sind mit bezahlter Spielzeit-Pflicht. Und dann gibt es noch die Kronos. Diese kosten 18 $ und können Ingame verkauft werden (sie ermöglichen 30 Tage Spielzeit) - ähnlich einem Plex in EVE-Online (wers kennt). Für ein Krono bekommt man eine hohe Summe an Platinmünzen - und kann sich bessere Ausrüstung leisten. Ist das Notwendig? Ich finde nicht... und es stört mich nicht weiter, wenn manche sich mit Echtgeld rausputzen.
Kann man es Solo spielen? Je nach Heldenklasse ist ein Solo-Spiel möglich, wenn auch etwas zäh - in einer guten Gruppe stehen einem ganz andere Wege offen. Dennoch kann man sich Solo durchbeißen und dies hat auch oft seinen eigenen Charm. Zur Not gibt es ja auch noch Gilden.
Das Spiel ist NICHT übersetzt und auf englisch. Muss man akzeptieren - wobei ich mit meinem uralten Schulenglisch immer noch zurecht komme. Man sollte jedoch die Menge an Text nicht unterschätzen - weniger die im Spiel - als vielmehr die auf externen Seiten über das Game - denn vieles kann man nachlesen und es gibt wichtige Informationen zu Mobs, Drops, Zonen, Skills, Spells, etc. im Netz.

Ich genieße zur Zeit eine herrlich unpolierte MMO-Erfahrung auf dem noch recht frischen TLP-Server "Oakwynd" und muss sagen, dass ich deutlich spannendere Momente erlebe als in aktuellen und polierten Titeln, wo ein Erfolgserlebnis das nächste jagt und alles smooth daherläuft. Everquest ist holprig, hat eine steile Lernkurve und ... gibts seit 1999 - merkt man, und ich finds gut.

Daumen hoch und reinschnuppern kostet nichts!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042493197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 14472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7264, 'last_played': 1709898075}
review: Roll a new character on a TLP. The important part is timing, so make sure you join the TLP when it is in its earlier days, like classic or kunark. It's the most punishing, yet strangely satisfying mmo I have ever played. This is before WoW so none of the industry standards are in place yet and creativity flourishes. The game is difficult to learn and even harder to master, but I just started playing it last year and am having a blast while I learn! Come join me in Oakwynd, I'll be waiting adventurer :)

author: {'steamid': '76561199404314136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 26405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26405, 'last_played': 1686160873}

author: {'steamid': '76561198007538349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1688890492}
review: I played this ages ago and thought "hey! a little nostalgia!" I've no problem with sub-ing to a game I enjoy playing but $15/mo is a little steep for such an old game. Also hiding a pretty important aspect of playing this on modern systems (UI size adjustment) behind that pay-wall is total garbage.

review: I think this game is absolute one of the best(If the only decent) MMO on the market, but Live has lost what it made Everquest fun, and the horrible service model requiring you to pay a subscription for the game's main form of class progression. Just awful, other then that it's a fun time waster which I wish had better quests. But I can't recommend playing this version of it, private servers are the way to go.

author: {'steamid': '76561199106795023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 2219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1731, 'last_played': 1693423298}
review: Very pay to play, your mercs get very expensive fast and you end up having to buy tokens or not using the mercs. Mercs just so happen to be most of your damage because you will hit like crap or will tank like crap and need mercs to help you especially early on. I got to level 22 and they were already costing 1 platinum and 5 gold. Hardly anything at that level gives more than a couple gold at best. You get to Blightmoore and the map doesn't even exist, there is nothing at all but your arrow. The quick bars are overly complicated for placing spells. The game pops up advertisement to subscribe in middle of battles. It's hard to tell if you are close to a mob because they will be hitting you from 10 players away, of course they will claim that this is lag but yet all their mobs do it every time. My laptop can handle WoW with no heat issues but this game on default setting causes my laptop to get hot. There are various other bugs and glitches throughout the beginning of the game showing they don't really care about anything beyond keeping the game working just enough to cash in so they can spend the money on hookers and blow. It's about time you merged your servers for this dead game. Sell off your extra servers and cut way back on the costs. There isn't enough players on most servers to justify even having so many different servers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067768594', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 40590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40590, 'last_played': 1490752587}
review:
This game has been made to be more like modern MMO's which to some will have devalued the game. For me I still have fun, I have over 10,000 hours on just one of many characters that I play.  There is no other MMO with the amount of content of this game. 

Most of the negative review I seen made a few mistakes. If you are starting out it is worth the sub to play on a Time Lock Progression TLP server. The newer the server to more low level players. You can later transfer of to another server if you choose too. Another great place to Start is Firiona Vie where almost all gear can be traded. You can easily gear up and level easily. Also there is a large player base on that server. 

Another thing it to set reasonable expectations in this game. Rushing for max level is not a good idea unlike other games where skipping content and getting max is the main goal. There is tons of content and lots of it rewards you throughout the game. Just getting to max level will have you at a serious disadvantage over the other max level players. It is those players that power level to max and then get frustrated when they are severely under powered. Make sure to have fun and explore, do quests, and missions. 

Next is play the class you enjoy not what is needed for raiding at end game. I see far to many make this mistake and hate the character they are playing. I have always been able to eventually get my main into a raiding guild. Some classes will be very slow to level, generally your support classes like Enchanters, Bards, and Clerics. If you want a simple class that is easy to level Ranger and Rouge are very easy to play and have abilities that make leveling quick. If you want a good all around character the Beastlord, Nerco, or Mage are hard to beat and can solo most content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059301495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1685803375}
review:
I have spent countless hours plying EQ, from the very day it hit store shelves in 1999, and on and off throughout the years. 
 What was once the envy of MMORPG's everywhere is now a steaming pile of hot garbage, all thanks to Daybreak Studios.   Not only do they incessantly try to push their over-priced 14.99 a month down your throat, they will automatically launch their website and its pop-ups on the web in the background while your game runs until you DO subscribe to their "FREE" game.  There are hundreds of games available on Steam that warrant your time and money, and this is not one of them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198375029180', 'num_games_owned': 1492, 'num_reviews': 919, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1664498387}
review:
EverQuest é um jogo de MMORPG clássico que deixou uma marca indelével na história dos jogos online. Lançado em 1999, o jogo foi um dos primeiros a oferecer um vasto mundo virtual persistente, repleto de aventuras e desafios para os jogadores explorarem. Uma das principais características que tornaram EverQuest tão icônico foi o seu mundo imersivo e rico em detalhes. O jogo apresenta um extenso mapa com inúmeras regiões, cidades, masmorras e territórios para os jogadores descobrirem. A variedade de raças jogáveis e classes permite uma ampla gama de opções de personalização de personagens, dando aos jogadores a liberdade de criar heróis únicos e com habilidades especializadas.

Outro destaque de EverQuest é o seu sistema de progressão. Os jogadores ganham experiência ao derrotar monstros e completar missões, permitindo que eles evoluam seus personagens e acessem novas habilidades e equipamentos. Essa progressão gradual cria uma sensação de conquista e crescimento contínuo, incentivando os jogadores a continuar explorando e enfrentando desafios cada vez maiores. EverQuest também é conhecido por sua comunidade ativa e envolvente. O jogo incentiva a interação entre os jogadores, seja na forma de grupos para enfrentar inimigos poderosos ou na formação de guildas para colaborar em objetivos comuns. A socialização e a cooperação entre os jogadores são essenciais para o progresso e sucesso no jogo.

Entretanto, é importante mencionar que EverQuest é um jogo desafiador e pode exigir um investimento significativo de tempo e dedicação. A curva de aprendizado pode ser íngreme para os novos jogadores, e o jogo é conhecido por sua dificuldade, especialmente em encontros com Bosses e masmorras de alto nível. Em suma, EverQuest é um clássico do gênero MMORPG que proporcionou aos jogadores uma experiência envolvente e imersiva em um mundo virtual vasto. Com seu mundo rico, progressão gratificante e uma comunidade dedicada, o jogo continua sendo uma opção atraente para os fãs de jogos online que procuram uma aventura épica e duradoura.

author: {'steamid': '76561199204228498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1107, 'last_played': 1707260724}
review: I have been playing EQ for over 20 years and I always come back to it over other RPG games. ALOT of changes have happened since I was a baby Druid, but mostly for the better. For a game to still be active and millions of players online, I think, and hope EQ will be here long after I am not. I am very thankful for the time I have been able to play this game and I will be playing until I am no longer able. Give it a try and if you need ANY assistance with anything, there are ALWAYS great players to help with any task or information on the game.

review: Everquest, the original MMO, the one that started it all.  Sadly, this game has NOT aged well.  It is so clunky and slow to respond as to be almost unplayable.  Nostalgia is probably the only reason anyone would approach this title and, frankly, for me that just simply isn't enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198994613983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5262, 'last_played': 1696551793}
review: I swear if Ever quest had a new player friendly experience and a better UI for new players that don't want a doctors degree in Ever quest this game could become more relevant today. They have a lot of things most MMO's just simply don't have today; like for starters they don't over monetize and they are not about breaking a game and selling you solutions. I get the dev team is basically just a community of people that love the game and are taking care of it, but like for the people who are really the devs and really are in control of the games future you could at least but some effort into that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029572433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 563361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 555907, 'last_played': 1693069095}
review:
It's got a steep learning curve and the graphics are dated but it's worth the effort,TLP servers are closet to the old school feel....I felt like I had stepped into a first person game of D and D when I first started playing 20 plus years ago...entering certain zones with your character,at night, could actually cause a bit of fear...the music,the atmosphere..was fantasic.It was called Evercrack for a reason...Nostalgic masterpiece unmatched in scope and depth.It's almost 25 years old...not sure how much longer it'll be around...

P.s. I pay for a premium account with in game gold from monster drops and selling gear in the bazaar....it doesn't have to cost real money if you have time to grind

author: {'steamid': '76561198148791861', 'num_games_owned': 52, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1683825186}

review:
EDIT* I was salty when I reviewed this. Gave it another shot and ignored the subscription stuff. After 10 hours it has grown on me quite a bit. EQII included. Just might have to consider at least trying it for a month soon.

Tried it out and already quit within about 10 minutes. Not sure what makes you guys think advertising paying for a full account within minutes of logging in on a level 1 is a good idea. I haven't touched the game, how would I know if I want to pay a full subscription for it? And on top of that, auto-opening a window for the subscription when you exit means I will never play this game. 

I'm mostly leaving a review to remind myself why I should never bother re-installing this again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966946809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1682999709}
review: Never played Everquest before, so I don't really have nostalgia for it.  I did find myself enjoying the slower pace, and having to talk to npcs sometimes to see if they have quests (I play WoW and FFXIV both of which have quest markers above npcs heads).  Can't give much insight into the game, but since it's brand new to me, it felt fun exploring the areas and not just rushing quests non-stop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054979270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 57339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4018, 'last_played': 1689740562}
review:
Just came back after many years away.  My, how things have changed - for the better!   They've managed to fix almost everything wrong with the original game.  (Now has quest list and a map.)  
  This is NOT a game for the super-impatient who call you an idiot if you can't get to max level the first day.   This game requires thought, planning, and patience.   In other words, what true gamers have been complaining is missing from essentially all the new games.  
  Yes, the graphics are dated, but the game is 24 years old.  Even so they've updated the graphics in a number of areas, so color me impressed.
   I'm back, and I'm going to be staying.  With 29 expansions to the original game, the world is so big it will literally take years to completely explore it.  YAY!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060339191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 7464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6899, 'last_played': 1687217360}
review:
"The grandfather of MMORPGs, still worth playing today"

Everquest is one of the original MMORPGs and has been around for over two decades. While the game may be showing its age in some aspects, it still remains a classic and worth playing for anyone interested in the history of the genre.

The graphics and art design in Everquest may be a bit dated, but the game still offers a variety of environments and character models that are well-designed and customizable. The game also features a variety of cosmetic items that allow you to personalize your character even further.

What really sets Everquest apart is its history and legacy. The game was groundbreaking when it first released, and it still offers a deep and immersive world that is filled with lore and history. The game also offers a variety of systems, such as crafting, tradeskills, and player housing, that are all fleshed out and offer a lot of depth.

The gameplay in Everquest is also well-done. The combat system is intuitive and offers a variety of abilities and strategies, and the class system offers a variety of playstyles to suit your preferences. The game also offers a variety of quests and activities, from solo quests to group dungeons and raids, that provide a lot of content to explore.

The community in Everquest is also one of the best in any MMORPG. The player base is friendly and helpful, and the game features a variety of social activities, from player housing to events and festivals. This makes playing the game feel like you are part of a community rather than just a player.

Of course, Everquest is not without its flaws. The game can be a bit overwhelming at times, with a lot of content to explore and learn. The game can also be a bit slow-paced compared to other MMORPGs, which may not be everyone's cup of tea.

Overall, if you're interested in the history of MMORPGs and want to experience one of the original games in the genre, Everquest is definitely worth playing. With its deep and immersive world, engaging story, and strong community, Everquest is a classic MMORPG that has stood the test of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124352974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 35605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6942, 'last_played': 1696377743}
review:
I played EverQuest from 1999 to 2008 and just got back into it in 2023 just to see how its changed and definitely missed it a little. Wish it could get a overhaul because it actually had more depth then most modern mmorpg's since, I remember i few years back hearing they were going to make EverQuest Next but the game fell through and it was really sad to hear. Quest line, epics, raiding, dungeons, and more carry more depth then any game since and the game play encouraged player to group up. If you can over the graphics and manage to make a group of friends in the game then the experience is definitely one you wont forget. 

Darkpaw Games or Daybreak Games if your seeing this I can tell you their are many old players looking for EQ to make a come back in some form but it needs to be done right (I'm related to 5 old players alone that still tell stories of crazy memories we had).

author: {'steamid': '76561198037915704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 48722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 450, 'playtime_at_review': 40309, 'last_played': 1711241102}
review:
Everquest is by far the most influential and ambitious MMORPG ever created. I don't think it's hyperbole to say it's historically one of the most important games ever created. It was not the first MMORPG, but it so completely defined the genre that every title since can trace it's inspiration back to it. While World of Warcraft perfected the formula, eventually claiming the commercial success crown, WoW owed almost everything to the framework Everquest set. A shockingly large number of big budget efforts failed to unseat Everquest in the intervening time. The ghost of Everquest continues to haunt newly released titles to this day. This is less a review and more a love letter to an all time classic.

Truthfully, firing up Everquest in 2023 if you never played it is an exercise in frustration and near pointlessness. It's enduring value is as a historical relic.  Nostalgically it remains perfection. Objectively it's no longer a good game. But having the ability to freely pop back in and go for a walk through the dungeons and landscapes that I explored around the turn of the millennia remains a pretty amazing blessing.

I can't begin to explain the awe, wonder, and terror that Everquest evoked as you explored its world in it's day. Arguably, Everquest was never a good game. Yet so powerful were the emotions it evoked that it basically didn't matter. Players were happy to have the best the technology of it's day could do; were just thrilled to have the opportunity to wander Norrath. That magic is gone now. Still, the memories remain. More polished, more enjoyable games have been released since. But none came close to reproducing that raw sense of wonder. Everquest's ambition was staggering. It's probably a miracle it worked at all.

The game has been dumbed down and made easy to experience alone. Now you can casually pop back in and explore the dark corners of Sebilis and Solusek Ro that were far too dangerous to poke around in it's day. There's a magic like that of an archaeologist in coming back and seeing areas that were left to the imagination a generation ago for the first time.

In an era where games shut down servers a year or two after release, I'm glad this game remains playable nearly a quarter of a century after it was birthed. Every gamer interested in the history of gaming owes themselves an hour or two to test drive it. It's glory days are long behind it, never to return. But Everquest's spot in gaming history remains secure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079639212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1698027671}
review:
Good camera; It's 40 feet behind me and stares at the ground, I can't tell where I'm going as a result.

I then closed the game and it forced open my browser without my permission to advertise a game I was already playing.

Edit: I decided to give it another go.

It launched in some hilariously large resolution that my 4k monitor does not support, then without touching a menu it resized to something like 420p. The game proceeded to deafen me with its music while I stared uncomprehendingly at a server menu that told me I wasn't good enough to play on whatever specific server I clicked.

I finally managed to get onto a server, made a character and muted the howls of the damned. The game minimized itself to a monitor that does not exist and I had to track down Windows help posts on how to recenter the program. This actually worked and just as I was preparing to play-

It minimized itself again and the recenter window trick no longer worked.

What is this monstrosity?

author: {'steamid': '76561197981903989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1289, 'last_played': 1676194478}
review: The interface is so archaic. I sit around and play old games all day long, so the age of the game isn't really a factor. This one was always obtuse. That's why it was so easy for WoW to swoop in and be what it was. Because this game has always refused to be enjoyable without tremendous effort on your part. It doesn't meet you half way. It won't answer the door when you knock. and the helping hands are tome after tome of esoteric rules and systems to parse through. Some games like that are worth it, some are not. For me, this one is not. All other factors aside, the swimming controls alone are enough to make me exit the game and uninstall it once in a while. If this game is for you, it doesn't need a recommendation because you've already been playing it twenty or more years now.

It's got some good points - more variety than almost any MMO out there - tons of different monsters, zones, etc. The gameplay at higher levels is tactical.

The engine is so old and clunky, though, and the servers so unpopulated nowadays that it's hard to fully recommend. There are better MMOs out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971183712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 9580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9580, 'last_played': 1625382268}
review:
In the land of Norrath, a world of magic and lore,
Lies a game that has captivated players for years,
EverQuest is its name, a pioneer of its time,
With races and classes, a world of endless possibilities to explore.

The gameplay is immersive, the world is vast and expansive,
With friends to group with, quests and challenges to tackle,
The developers are dedicated, their passion and commitment evident,
Constantly updating, the game continues to evolve and improve, never stagnant.

In EverQuest, the community is strong and tight-knit,
Players from all over come together to form guilds and friendships,
To take on epic raids and conquer daunting foes,
In this world of adventure and danger, where the only limit is your own imagination.

If you're looking for a game that offers a truly unique and engaging experience,
EverQuest is it, a timeless classic that has stood the test of time,
With its rich lore and diverse gameplay, it offers something for everyone,
Give it a try, and you'll be drawn into its enchanting world, A timeless effort - sublime.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978567874', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 130406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130406, 'last_played': 1661828125}

review:
It is still the best MMORPG, if you are patient enough to play it. Why? Because it has kinda legacy-like mechanics, still gets new players (not that much though), has a reasonable monetisation (not a pay to win). However, I have one issue with the subscription prices. I think it is pretty high, but I understand why. The quality of the content...

I must add this edit: if you are a long time player or just a casual one who enjoy its long-term progression, you should use maps.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993521471', 'num_games_owned': 1307, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1669315704}
review: As MMORPG fans of a certain age can tell you, there’s a kind of magic that early entries in the MMORPG genre had that newer games can’t quite recreate. Maybe that’s why EverQuest is still attracting gamers, despite making its debut back in 1999. Today, it’s something of an elder statesman in the MMORPG market, and it still has a very active regular player base.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021570837', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 10884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6463, 'last_played': 1709219473}
review:
I'm a very solo person.  I like playing solo, and not dealing with other players.  The  game is pretty soloable up to 50-60.  Past 60 is just crazy to level solo.  Everything hits way too hard and everything is a big pull.

I'd love to see the game become a bit more solo-friendly to those who want it?  Especially to a subscriber ( maybe a buff? ) - 

Otherwise the game can be fun.  I don't  mind the grind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198298683483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 6965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6960, 'last_played': 1668483823}
review: TLPs are controlled by gold farmers and bots, with Daybreak turning a blind eye, because said gold farmers are a major source of income for them because of subscriptions. In the end you will probably find one gold farmer for 4 players. They will make your game miserable. You will quit and come back forgetting how bad it was. You will crave that old school feeling, but never attain it, because Daybreak is not Sony, but rather a company owned by a financial corporation that only cares about the profit the game makes. I still recommend the game, but I don't want you to get your hopes up. There is always Project 1999 and World of Warcraft when you finally realize how much its changed, til then, enjoy it for what it is, a hollow illusion of what it once was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047932072', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1668346326}
review: The game is awesome to play but, according to the official EverQuest forums, if you are running the game on an operating system above that of Windows 7 then there may be a chance that you won't be able to complete all of the quests in the game.  It is also recommended that if you do not have a post Windows 7 operating system that you run the game as an administrator in order to maximise your chances of being able to complete any quest in the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970753301', 'num_games_owned': 856, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1667516915}
review:
If you played this 20 years ago and are excited to go back, well, if you actually have a personal connection to your character's name, odds are it will have had between 1 and ??? number of Xs added to the end of its name thanks to 20 years of server mergers and the seemingly arbitrary and capricious renaming decisions automatically (or, worse, not automatically) made by the game.

Otherwise if you just want to play it fresh, uh ... no, you really do not want to play it fresh.  I would never have started playing EverQuest at the time if it had not literally been the first real entry in the "3D MMORPG" genre.  Look, I have a LOT of cherished memories of my time playing, but the actual logistics of playing and the endless frustration experienced when losing hours of progress are not things I ever want to repeat in my life.  I have quit games for far less than "it might take two hours to get your stuff back after you died"

author: {'steamid': '76561198090682811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2366, 'last_played': 1667136033}
review:
Everquest is excellent. So much nostalgia from playing as a kid on my older brother's account. Game worked perfectly!

My two complaints are that I can't move my old character from my brother's account to an account I've made and that there's no option to start in the OG starting zones. 

Overall love this game and would highly recommend to anyone interested in MMORPGs or games where the quests are never ending. Everquest is an appropriate name since one could seriously quest for 100s or 1000s of hours and be nowhere near completing all the quests available

review:
It's EverQuest, a seminal entry in the MMORPG genre. Pick a populated server, join a guild, break out the Doritos and Mountain Dew, and party like it's 1999.

I play on Bristlebane. Feel free to message me and we can kill bog rats together.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992587371', 'num_games_owned': 661, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1666350415}
review:
I want to be clear right now that I am more than any other time making use of the most literal interpretation of the steam 'not recommend' button, and not using it like it is typically used to indicate quality.

I did not play enough to actually gather a proper experience as to whether the quality is good or bad (not that I would even need to tell you. This game has a reputation for a reason), because the game feels its age so damn hard that simply doing the most basic things were a pain in the ass, even with the really subpar tutorials trying to do their best to explain it to you. But this is not a flaw of the game itself, but rather likely due to technical limitations they had back in 1999 that they either couldn't fix, or  genuinely thought certain things were not a bad idea back then. Either is possible due to how old this game is.

So like, this is the type of game you'd be hard pressed to find someone enjoying when they have never played Everquest before, so in that light I don't recommend the game to anyone wondering if they want to give it a try. It's free, so go nuts, but holy shit does it show its age.

author: {'steamid': '76561198805795755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3053, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2225, 'last_played': 1669687138}

Recommend that you mod the maps if you play though.

review:
Everquest is the first game I got heavily into as a kid.
As an adult it's not as difficult as I remember... maybe because I have better reasoning abilities. However, it's a lot more fun as an adult because I know what's going on.
Pretty much the same old game I remember. More difficult than modern MMOs that hold your hand the whole way. 10/10 would recommend for anyone who wants a challenge more than graphics that test GPU performance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113848693', 'num_games_owned': 1170, 'num_reviews': 345, 'playtime_forever': 775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1663268967}
review:
[h1]Comentario Analítico: "EverQuest"[/h1] 

EverQuest no es un nombre muy recordado últimamente. La última vez que me interesé por esta franquicia fue con EverQuest Next antes de su cancelación, desde entonces no volví a prestarle mucha atención. Recientemente me enteré de cuenta todavía con servidores abiertos y es totalmente accesible mediante Steam, así que tuve que instalarlo.

Claramente no es la versión de antaño, esa no la opera Daybreak Game Company, pero por si te interesa existe un proyecto legal hecho por fans llamado "Project 1999 EverQuest" o "EverQuest Classic" cuya función es la de abrir servidores como si se tratase del EverQuest de su época.

Ya hablando de la versión disponible mediante Steam, está bastante actualizada y modernizada en función a las posibilidades de su motor, es una experiencia interesante para los que disfrutamos de este género, pero es importante advertir que las mecánicas y características ya obsoletas siguen vigentes, tratándose de un MMO muy desafiante y cuyo ritmo lento se conserva. 

Es de una época en la que la aventura de un MMO nacía en el juego y se desarrollaba en tu imaginación, creyendo que esos golpes sin feedback y con animaciones robóticas eran combates de magnitudes calamitosas.

Le pesa los años y es indiscutible que está más dirigido a quienes lo jugaban o a quienes les da curiosidad, no a un público genuinamente interesado en empezar en este mundo. Pero si te interesa, es un clásico que sigue contando con una comunidad relativamente activa, que se reduce a dos tercios de su número total si no contamos a los bots, pero sigue siendo bastante gente para tratarse de un producto tan añejo.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Es EverQuest, y encima abierto de manera oficial. Totalmente recomendado si se es consciente de los detalles propios de su longevidad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032998559', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 245, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1657619250}

author: {'steamid': '76561198064998681', 'num_games_owned': 2308, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 70913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47543, 'last_played': 1706890333}
review:
The people I used to play Everquest with are now all either dead, or old. This MMO regularly outlives the players. 

It's also a good game. Really! But when tasked with thinking of something substantial to say about the game that I've returned to over 20 years after I first played it, that ended up being the first thing that came to mind. 

It has legs. It will outlive us all. Fear it.

If you're good with that, and don't mind outdated graphics? This game is where a lot of other games got their good ideas, and has decades of content available. Dive in. Just, like... make sure your affairs are in order. Or don't, I dunno. Maybe someone will have a rez.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970269345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 28092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1704320251}
review: Having last played Everquest for about a year back in 2003, I was amazed to find that there is still a flourishing and friendly community on the Time Locked Progression Yelniak Server that just opened back in May 2022. After trying WoW Classic and finding the game far too easy and boring, I am having a real blast with the challenge that is Everquest. Monsters in the starting zones killed me within seconds of spawning my character. Dungeons are unforgiving and relentless. Now I am nearing level thirty, I am still wearing the same gear that I had when I started at level one. Everquest is the Dark Souls of MMO's and I am loving every second of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057293491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 38221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34428, 'last_played': 1693969288}
review:
Pros:
It is good that Ever Quest is still available to play since it is one of the first online multi-player RPG games that anyone playing online games should know about. Something that younger generations should at least play for awhile and learn about in regards to the history of online gaming and where allot of it started. It is also initially free-to-play, thus you won't loose much but your time. There is also so much never ending quest content that it definitely lives up to the title of Ever Quest as the original creators intended. It is also very stable and very well worked on since it has been around and maintained for so long.

Cons:
Unlike the 'classic' Ever Quest, the importance of player interaction has been downgraded since it's glory days of 1999. You can practically solo through most levels depending on the class you choose. Though this is not per-say bad, the original Ever Quest required you to group with other players from the beginning, was very slow paced, and demanding of player class cooperation. Now, the original zones are dead like me: empty, forgotten, and occupied by bored and lonely NPCs. You can relive the original zone progression if you choose, and if you know which zones to go to, but you will for sure be doing so alone, and will need previous experience with the game to know how to get your new character to your lonely racial starting zone and know what quest are there. Playing in the original zones will also be much slower. However, there is active guilds in game in which you can find other players to interact with and progress to higher level raid content. So there is options of playing with others, but not as required as it was in classic EQ, and will have to progress through the newer zones to find players, leaving the old zones abandoned in a hot car like a forgotten child with crackhead parents. You are also limited to only select severs as free-to-play, so keep that in mind as well, though there is plenty of servers to choose from over all.

Overall Recommendation:
I am giving it a recommendation for the nostalgic availability, free-to-play option, game stability, and lack of continuous issues as some games have. If you like those things to run smooth in a game, and like to solo allot, then the DayBreak Ever Quest is a good choice. If you have active friends or family that like to play games with you, it would also be a good option. Probably not a good choice for impatient PVP players that like non-stop high player content and consistent player interactions. You will have to be very pro-active to get player interactions. Always try a free-to-play option first if available since many games seem to have issues with paid subscriptions.

(Note: This comment is based on Free-To-Play experience, thus subscription based players may have other issues not relevant to this review.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197968495022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 4289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1459, 'last_played': 1663988367}
review:
Subscribed yesterday... (note that 15$ is pretty expensive for a 20+ years old game)
Played a bit yesterday.
I tried to play again today but for whatever reason my account is locked : they decided to force a 2 steps authentication with phone and ask me to add a phone number to my account.
Problem is, when I try to do this, the system replies that it is unable to process the request.
I create a ticket...20 hours later still no news...so I can't play.
And I'm a paying customer...
I don't want to imagine how they treat the free to play players ^^

Update : I finally got an answer. Actually you can expect one reply every 24H.
Unfortunately for me, the guy at customer support misunderstood my problem and 3 days later...I'm still waiting for them to solve it. Hopefully, I might have another shot in 24H...time for them to reply...

author: {'steamid': '76561198049877485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1342, 'last_played': 1658603262}
review: Looks old, feels old, filled with confusing nonsense that, even once it makes sense, doesn't really impress me. No idea why this is still more popular than EQ2 when EQ2 did everything this game did far better, and Final Fantasy XI did everything better than both of them combined. FFXI may be almost as old as EQ but it's not nearly as impenetrable and clunky and janky. Maybe you'll get some nostalgia value out of this one if you played it when Bill Clinton was still president -- I sure didn't. Give it a try since it's free to play, but if you appreciate even moderately modern convenience in MMO gaming, this will be an immediate turn-off to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198846109716', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 51196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51196, 'last_played': 1657065738}
review:
Played from '99 to 2006 and visited over the years. Last month, I gave Yelinak, the new Time Locked Progression server a try.  After just two weeks of toxic, repugnant behavior from people in their statistical forties, I contacted Daybreak to permanently close my accounts in favor of preserving fond memories over new realities. You can't go home again.

If you're coming back for a bit of nostalgia, know that Daybreak Games has a race-to-the-bottom ethic of community conduct (but only a cynical person would call this a community): Train, gank, harass, afk botting, all of that is fine. Antisocial apparently sells. Meanwhile, camps/camping/ksing is deemed to no longer exist. So acrimony abounds. The vast majority of players I met seemed to be aggravated about Daybreak and the game as it exists now. Why they continue playing is beyond me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980581353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1656886675}
review:
Going to keep this really simple in the hopes that at least one person reads it and decides not to waste their time or money.

Why this game is shit: 

The player base - It's a 50/50 mix of angry hostile basement dwelling sweats that treat a 23 year old elf simulator like it's the next up and coming e-sport and bot farmers. It's not uncommon to see 1 person running around followed by 5 bots that are being operated by 3rd party software. The real players you'll interact with have exactly the personality you'd expect from someone that hasn't left their basement since they logged into the game over 2 decades ago. If you're new you will be treated in a hostile manner for not understanding all of the intricacies of a 23 year old video game and often discarded in favor of someone who does. 
 
The game is broken - After 2 decades of just dumping shallow content patches on players without worrying about silly things like bug fixes and optimization the game barely functions. You can look forward to enjoying frequent freezes and crashes for seemingly no reason. If you do manage to miraculously make it into the game itself you'll soon be plagued with issues like complete UI resets, crashing while zoning, crashing due to resolution changes, crashing due to random disconnects and crashing because its Wednesday and why not?

The game is dead - The game is tagged as an MMO but in reality its closer to a Single player RPG. In order to properly enjoy this game you're going to need pay multiple subscription fees for multiple accounts because nobody actually wants to play this game with other players (you can't hardly blame them given the personality of the average Everquest player.) The TLP servers offer a "Truebox" ruleset to prevent this but DBG/Darkpaw do not enforce it so any decent hunting spot/camp is gobbled up by 1 person playing 6 accounts. 

The economy - It's nonexistant and revolves around trading subscription tokens that are purchased with real money for items instead of in game currency. As im writing this review there is currently someone auctioning an item for 35 Krono ($629.65) on the newest TLP server. Yes this is real, you can't make this shit up, yes the developers are that dumb. 

I could give you a hundred more reasons not to play this game but to be honest I don't care enough to list them. Save your time and your money and don't bother downloading this game. The developers gave up on producing anything meaningful over a decade ago and instead their only focus is cosmetic microtransactions and selling in game tradeable subscription tokens for nearly $20 a pop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198382952437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1598002945}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023724827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 36560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36550, 'last_played': 1656742704}
review:
DO NOT risk playing this game in steam, it will get your account suspended.

Game itself is OK. Company should be shut down.  My account was suspended for "cheating" out of the blue.  A suspended account can no longer log in or form any communication with the company because you must log in in order to have any sort of contact with them.  Phone numbers listed pretty much tell anyone calling they are SOL.

Additionally this suspension occurred directly after making a purchase and claiming my item in game, but no other explanation than Cheating.  So not sure if on top of a shady company, they are running a scam?  This part really has me scratching my head.

I'm not really sure if this was due to steam or not, or maybe I wasn't supposed to have exp boost items on the TLP I was on. In any of these cases, I'm not really too sure what is going on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030608391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 301958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 739, 'playtime_at_review': 219059, 'last_played': 1711166492}
review:
IMO nothing beats a classic MMO like this. I have played everquest through its iterations since the beginning. The game came out in 1999 and went through some trying times, but then was purchased by Daybreak and they have managed to breathe some life back into it. 

For a game that has been out as long as this and managed to maintain a player base, and for a game that continues to release refreshed servers and ideas (random loot servers for example) it still brings a sense of nostalgia and accomplishment to my gaming needs.

Thank you Daybreak.

author: {'steamid': '76561198966130379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1659182085}
review: I have five hours in this game according to Steam but boy oh boy, do I have 175,320 hours+. I was around when the expansions were released, when you had to go out and buy them off the store shelves and put in the key codes! I grew up with this game, lan parties with family and friends, dreaming about being a dwarf walking my way to school, imagining myself decapitating Ambassador DVinn in Crushbone and taking his black heart. It's a good game, there will never be anything like it ever again, and no, this game is not the same as it used to be. We will all still be waiting for this game to make a comeback someday. What beautiful gem, it still holds every inch of my heart! Thank you for an amazing childhood. Family reunions will never be the same without you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056921937', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1651355096}
review:
it's the best MMORPG I have ever played - Yes it may be difficult on the classic servers such as Project 1999 servers. 
Everybody is mostly so kind and generous even if they don't know you. it's not so competitive or easy like (basically - every other MMORPG) out there. Everyone I've met there helps you out, rather than something like WoW which is competitive, easy, soloable, whereas on EQ you literally need to group up to level up (unless you're a longer and mastered soloing which is easier for a few classes). You make friends this way, too. 
It's very much based on D&D. The developers put a ton of work in it. I stay stick with classic EQ - it's an old time game but anyone who has played says it has the greatest community. Try it out on Project 1999- the Green Server is the best one. 
Started in 1999 and just started it out again but not on Steam - it's the most rewarding, fascinating, friendly and community-wise the greatest MMO over. 
Don't be afraid to play a game from 1999 and past gamers will get a heavy dose of Nostalgia. And an awesome real community not based on individuality and greed. Loved this game since 1999 when it fully came out.
