author: {'steamid': '76561198033505275', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 33225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33225, 'last_played': 1547176366}
review: Despite the outdated looking graphics and animations, this is at its core one of the best MMO experiences that you can have. By subscribing to the game you are getting 2 versions of the game with the TLP servers and the current live service. While the majority of my time is with the older Everquest which can be experienced through the TLPs, the live version is no slouch giving you a whole new way to play the game and opening up more content then you could complete in even the 553 hours I have listed for play time. If you  want a world you can easily fall into where community actually matters then Everquest is a game that you need to experience first hand.

review: Still the best MMORPG on the market. The only catch is it very hard to find people to level with on free servers. I highly recommend trying out the Progression servers. I was late to the latest server opening, but I'm still finding groups. If you haven't tried Everquest before, there is nothing else like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995133816', 'num_games_owned': 765, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 10296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8463, 'last_played': 1654539898}
review:
Insanely addictive old-school MMO that is closer based to D&D rules/classes than other games you might be used to. Only really worth playing imo when a new TLP (Time Locked Progression) Server launches as the live servers are extremely top heavy (only max level chars). 

One major downside to this game is something called "Krono" which is like Plex in EVE and WoW Tokens. However they are more like Plex in how they are a tradeable currency with real money value so there has been a lot of toxic people play the game to earn money from it; this means ruining a lot of the old school experience sadly. 

However if you're bored of the new age MMOs, I stil highly recommend giving this one a try despite the Krono and farmers and if you can overlook the 2001 graphics.

(TLP requires a subscription, it isn't free to play like the main servers!)

(Also to note I have so many more 100's of hours played, but I used to play prior to it being on steam so it looks like my play count is lower. Played on and off since 2000 and coming back to TLP's)

review: Uninstalling this garbage is a pain in my ***. Before you subject yourself to this F2P game, just remember that you will not be able to uninstall it without some bs to go through. You have to go into your steam files and delete everything except the registry files and hide the game on your steam library page. When I researched all this crap, the only way to uninstall it properly is if you downloaded it on the actual Daybreak Games website. This whole situation is just gross...

author: {'steamid': '76561198006400253', 'num_games_owned': 1057, 'num_reviews': 217, 'playtime_forever': 7634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2147, 'last_played': 1598279407}
review:
Playing on Original EQ servers is a blast. World of Warcraft successfully emulated EQ with Vanilla and that's why it was such a big hit, but now it's a watered down mess, and EQ is still just... EverQuest!

I've never played EQ before because I didn't like how it looked, especially as a kid. But now that I'm older I can appreciate the time it takes to level up, be social, and find groups and/or just level solo. It's extremely fun and I have multiple characters at level 5 already.

I'm sure even the free version is great though tbh since you're working with all the new quality of life stuff as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995194600', 'num_games_owned': 271, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 24939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6042, 'last_played': 1698085499}
review:
It's hard, frustrating and has a steep learning curve. But i recommend it to anyone who enjoys old-school MMO's.

Update: yeah... picked it up again around 1.5 months ago and I'm addicted.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969730797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 8659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6872, 'last_played': 1691002550}
review:
The main issue with this game is unless you have a seriously strong guild willing to help you have will have no chance getting any decent gear, all named camps are taken 24/7 by people boxing in toxic guilds who will just take camps from you if you were lucky enough to get them. because of this they exert utter dominance over the in game economy charging insane prices for gear that should be reasonably obtainable and surprise and surprise the camps which can make you money are taken by people boxing 24/7.

All this on the premium servers which you pay for and are meant to have rules against toxic and abusive behaviour and boxing is banned but yet it is never enforced.

It was fun going back to for a while but when reality hits home on how the toxic players with no GM oversight have ruined this game you give up and go back waiting for Pantheon.

review: I was only interested in returning to the "traditional" aradune server. Since I started two weeks ago I have to pre-queue for about 2-5 hours a day just to log in. Since I started I've been disconnected about 8 or so times having to re-queue again. I AM PAYING FOR THIS SERVICE, this is NOT a f2p server. In return they offer us a 25% exp increase. Which would be great for those not already level 50 or who are able to play. I strongly recommend if your thinking of trying this piece of nostalga to find another game. This company clearly does not care about its hobbiests other than the value of their wallets.

review: It was my first major MMO back before it had any expansions, it's still fun and has very active community depending on the server you join. Subscribers can use the time/lock servers which allows you to play the game as it originally was, and it progresses to the next expansion after a few months pass, it has been interesting and enjoyable to join the latest timelocked server, still as fun as i remember it to be. you do have to work at gaining in this one, it's old-school and if your looking for modern game perks, it's not for you. Advancement can be a bit of a grind, but isn't too bad if you find a good party.

author: {'steamid': '76561198199886655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13648, 'last_played': 1458000058}
review:
This is a game rich in adventure and very group orientated in its history. While the release of each expansion made older content more soloable at lower levels, the newer the content, the more the game requires grouping to develop your character.

Game requires subtle tactics and careful planning, achieved with a multitude of abilities from many classes that allow for the manipulation of most monster mechanics, that enables players to achieve, what feels to be, extraordinary feats. The peculiar nature of the game mechanics combined with the harsh nature of the content will even adapt you to a second nature of exploitation of those predictable game mechanics, the position of your character to give you that extra second of monster pathing to you, location based spell interrupts nullified if starting a cast in a corner, strafing left and right to increase the distance the mob runs while fleeing for your life. Maybe you can call these examples a flawed game design, but you'll find they give the game character and will be grateful for them being there.

This game is far from a spam fest like other games, it needs tact. If you find a group of friends to play this game for the first time, you'll have an experience like no other.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988164044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 1586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1655600074}

review: Honestly, it's a lot of nostalgia for me.  When I read "You're in our world now" on the original EQ box in 1999, I had no idea how for real it would be.  I've played a lot of MMOs, but I always find myself rolling up a new toon on the TLPs.  Tons of fun and it's made even better if you can get friends to join in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051194709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1598783541}
review: Outside console platform games, this is the ONE that started it all for enjoying MMORPG titles - for me!  If the content only maintained your grind and your enjoyment, just as many other titles, the people in the trenches did as well as we all were poised to conquer anything Norrath would throw at us.  I am writing this review in sincere gratitude to my friend Andrew V., a RL friend, who introduced this game to me and allowed me to fight alongside him and the others on Saryrn server with his guild "Order of the Phoenix" -- may he R.I.P. my brother, my friend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003926432', 'num_games_owned': 29, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1586003202}
review:
I tried it as a non-paying user.    Literally like 3 people in the whole game were online that were lower than max level.   When you do searches for who is online, the people in bazaar in offline mode show up for 95% of the results.
Play project 1999 instead.   Much more people online in my opinion.

review: Everquest has changed over the years, and for once  they fucked up at some point, allowing people to BOX ( use muiltiple clients and use 5+ toon) has ruined this game for the worse, whole guilds as a box and they camp shit sonoone else can get it and rack up prices, people boxing full actual groups out of an area because *they can* this game has turned into a joke and im sad I came back to this shit, Darkpaw... why would you make sure people no longer have fun at eq?

author: {'steamid': '76561198181315501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 94649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63020, 'last_played': 1708995939}
review: I've played EQ now, off and on, since 1999.  It is the first true 3-D graphical MUD.  The granddaddy of most fantasy MMORPGS.  Though the game has changed A LOT over the subsequent 20 years, I still keep coming back to it.  Whether you are a new or returning player,  Norrath is a wonderful world to explore.  A vibrant community, numerous class/race combinations to try out, tons of quests to complete, tradeskills to master, dungeons to explore, raids to conquer, loots to find, AA points to gain, and adventures to be had.  While there are perks to being an All Access Member(monthly subscriber), I have found being a F2P player is just as viable.  Hats off to Darkpaw Games for continuing this great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994992123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 61682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1283, 'last_played': 1708177983}

author: {'steamid': '76561198377459855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 300678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4933, 'playtime_at_review': 91525, 'last_played': 1711254408}
review: Been playing this game for years. I enjoy the market aspect of this game because it's real players buying your stuff! I enjoy going out and killing stuff to sell on the market because I know others need this stuff I kill to advance their crafting skills. I've played other mmorpg and prefer and always come back to this one because of the community. I enjoy showing up at the newbie places and healing people or buffing folks when I can! It's a great place to just hang out with some cool folks. :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198135652727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 306170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4202, 'last_played': 1655953991}
review:
I've played this gem on and off since 1999. I've played custom servers, I've leveled a few different classes, I've seen the rise and fall of this game and the slow rebirth. I remember when it was verant, sony, and now the departed Daybreak team. I've seen the money grabs, the introduction of quality of life updates, pointless zones, etc. All that being said, this was THE golden age of MMOs and nothing has felt close enough to be enjoyable since. 10/10 will keep coming back for more because when that itch arises, there is no other MMO to truly scratch it.

EDIT : After playing on Mangler until DoN and playing Mischief up to Omens(2nd best expansion after PoP IMO), I have put so many more hours in this game. It has ruined me. It has ruined any hope I have of enjoying other MMOs because I know what they SHOULD be and refuse to be. I research and try newer games and TBH they suck. They suck so bad. Here's to hoping Pantheon doesn't blow. Long live EQ!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022561115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 37817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29877, 'last_played': 1677455287}
review:
For new players hoping to try this game out here in 2020.

The game is still alive, you will find a decent community for the most part, and not to stressful finding a guild in 2020 unlike other MMO's such as WoW, ESO, Destiny, Ext...

Also for new players "I've played since launch" so I can't stress that the game CAN be very intimidating and overwhelming when learning the basics, but once you get the lvl 50 the game starts to make ALOT more sense, "Tip: ask people for help if you get stuck" because again, the community has been nice to me for the most part and I hope they treat you the same! Good Luck and enjoy a very nice classic MMO 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198050237511', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1620120168}
review:
Está bueno. Es un juego de 17 años ya y sigue de pie. Aunque la comunidad es 80% veterana por lo que los primeros niveles no vas a encontrarte con mucha gente nueva, salvo personajes secundarios. Pero lo bueno es que son solidarios para enseñarte. La variedad de clases lo hace llamativo. Y su lore extenso te da muchas horas de descubrimiento hasta llegar al endgame.
Su interface es poco intuitiva pero al poco tiempo te acostumbrás. Además el movimiento no es de los mejores. También el sistema de batalla no es a lo que uno está acostumbrado, pero hay que tener en cuenta que es un juego del 2003.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977074449', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 10858, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10543, 'last_played': 1588534257}
review:
This game is definitely hard for newer gamers to get into, BUT for good reason.  This game actually encouraged hard work with slower rewards.
GRANTED this is definitely more of a nostalgia game, but they have added more tools to help with soloing (Mercenaries etc).  It's still quite fun, but may take a little longer customizing your User Interface.
Some people mention maps being an issue, but all you need to do is download Brewall's Maps and select them for zones that don't provide a map (most are rather comprehensive).

Some of the other features do take getting used to, but anyone who used to play EQ can easily adapt and relearn. (i.e. players who actually had gaming etiquette and weren't complete trolls like half the gamers nowadays)

Some people will say it's slow, etc, but patience is a virtue.   World of Warcraft became extremely boring to me over time (no matter how many maxed characters I had, the most fun was in leveling newer characters as opposed to doing repetitive daily quests).

So many games provide faster leveling and more flashy loot in a shorter amount of time, but where is there any satisfaction in what you've achieved?  

Give the game a shot if you're looking for something that might actually be more similar to D&D without making things overly simplified (even D&D online was questionable)..

Everquest will make you raise individual skills, including language skills, depending upon what you want to accomplish.  Including some of the ALternative Advancement (AA) skills, you can make more basic skills somewhat useful for certain situations.  Or learning to disarm or intimidate enemies may be useful.   There is quite a variety in what you can focus on improving.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973724002', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 35972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28375, 'last_played': 1594051534}

review: A retro oldschool mmorpg classic, one of the first actually pre-dating the legendary world of warcraft. Dont let my steam game play time fool you, I played the hell out of this game back in the day max leveling a barbarian and mid maxing a few alts, now in 2020 its to hard to get back into, especially with its sequel here on steam and nicely populated. Its a good game and you should check it out for the historical aspect of it, as it will always be an important part of video game history!

author: {'steamid': '76561198046706175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 47266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47266, 'last_played': 1576209377}
review:
If you want nostalgia and to dip into your childhood for a bit? Feel free to hop on a TLP/Live to get your fill. 

Don't let "true box servers" fool you. You can 100% use the same computer to run several accounts, it just takes the right program and changing 1 thing....

Automation software? Of course. I mean.... sure that guy is running 20+ chars at once with 20 computers/mouse/keyboards.... he's totally legit!  Hell, on Mangler there was a guy competing with raid guilds in openworld. When he failed, he'd just train/troll.

Want to actually play an MMO with people and not sociopaths? Avoid at all costs. I probably have thousands of hours outside of steam in this, it's the horrible drug that keeps dragging me back.  After this last TLP though, I've had my fill. I've met some really cool people along the way though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995793536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 4551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4551, 'last_played': 1583714365}
review: I really love this game. I originally started playing this in 2003 and spent about 1000+ hours. It was the best MMO i have ever played and never ran out of things to do. I have played about 15 MMO's since then and nothing beats it still. I would say WOW was second to this game. If you love crafting, questing, story line, lore, massive zones, raids, pvp and more you will love this game. Unlike Wow you could take every skill and craft anything, plus you had 1000's of alternative advancement points to speed to make sure you character was specialized and could take down anything. It was a lot of work and the game really challenge you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978676222', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1054, 'last_played': 1585120617}

AFTERTHOUGHT: Playing with a free account and don't feel any limitations or need to purchase the subscription.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193783213', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 28702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1370, 'last_played': 1709520614}
review:
Having grown up knowing about, but never playing, EverQuest I was always interested in trying it out. I was aware of its' legacy and how immersive the world was eager to jump in. I have had experience in other MMOs that were popular at the time for me like WoW, DDO, LoTR, GW, etc. so I knew the "ropes" of the genre. EQ proved to be a different beast...Let start by saying I very much enjoy this game and I can say I enjoy it on level that others just never did for me but it is not without a fairly steep learning curve (IMO). 

With the game being 20 years old I knew going into this that it would be a bit of chunky experience and for me that was true. While all the "features" of any MMO are there, they are often hard to find sometime or overtly "manual" which in itself was a reason many of my friends moved on from the game while I tried and tried again. This is a game that requires patience to play but is deeply rewarding once one overcomes the learning curve. To that end I strongly recommend the tutorial with the understanding that personally I found it a boring slog. Once you get into Norrath however, the game shines. There is a sense of exploration, drawing map in a dungeon as you move through it, reading quests and learning the names of locations and NPCs and I enjoyed the slow pace of it all. Rather than rushing from one quest to another and another with the goal of racing to the end, this game embodies the "it is not a race but a marathon" mindset. No you  do not need to buy any of DayBreak currency or items as they do not impact your ability to the play the game, rather this game was slow paced by design. I feel as if I know more about the areas I have explored in this game thanany other MMO because without quest markers, or UI directional overlays I have to read and understand each aspect. I have to learn how to move through zones and how they connect. 

All in all I have only done a few dungeons so far and have barley scratched the surface. For patience players looking for a piece of history, and a game that rewards the loyal, EQ worth exploring. With a low (free) cost of entry the game should be a "must have" in everyone's library and should be experienced at least once.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991798166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 21617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20912, 'last_played': 1584352308}
review: Maybe not the 'very first' MMO on the market. But it is the very first MMO that was in the first/3rd person perspective. Released back in 1999 in the 'Golden age of gaming', and originally played with 56k modems. Still a classic to this day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011713616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 47633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47383, 'last_played': 1677273479}
review: The daybreak membership is screwed up. If you're not an old player you don's get silver status after your membership expires, so all the stuff you get with all access is gone. The worst part is that the 8 character slots you're supposed to have poof and you can't even use the characters. They say you can only use the characters you created before membership but that is false. You can only use the two lowest level characters even if you haven't gained any AA's for other's. My two original toons have been locked but i can use toons i made while membership was active. I will no longer put any money into this game or play the F2P. You have ruined the membership system and the game for that matter.

review: people keep saying oh no cash shop and loot box's and such.... there is nothing that really makes any of those boxs worth it unless you want a specific mount skin from the box.. just like any other game out nowadays.  and yeah its alot easier and you will end up needing to sub for the AA's and such late game. the people that are saying the low level zones are empty and they cant find people are playing on dead servers. very active on select servers. (mangler TLP) and FV for live where you can play without a sub and you wont need one till about lvl 50+ for your AA's and merc it will help you can make money to buy a krono for a sub in game but on FV that will be difficult for new players who arn't multi boxing 6 characters to pay for 1 sub. (3.2 million plat) the game is very much alive and well

author: {'steamid': '76561198090283239', 'num_games_owned': 28, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 135814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129124, 'last_played': 1683854006}
review: I played everquest since 2000 the game has negated some of its best content and features with each expansion where this game has a strong place in my heart. I met my husband here went through a massive cross country move and lost people I've cared about in game. I would find it hard to recomend it to a new player.  There are no maps , many empty servers and a lack of players in areas. Past level 60 the game becomes almost unplayable because all the content turns into high end player content and you no longer can get a group for most of it.

I will defend myself and the game saying "once upon a time" you had to explore and deal w/ real problems. Who will attack me, who will help me? If you want a real rpg, then this is for you, thanks to WOW, you get to just spend money to find your body and recover the exp. you lost...In the old days of playing this game you could get rezed, but not get all you gear, because it was still on your dead body...Best realistic MMoRPG, and to keep their subscribers made it easier...You all know like WOW...

author: {'steamid': '76561197965399470', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 26538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9241, 'last_played': 1641945483}
review: EverQuest is an MMO from a different era. It is much more like D&D 2nd edition than any MMO before or since. The group mechanic is unequaled and I have come back after 15 years away because of those things. It is pretty hard to get into the current build because it is so different from what i remember but the progressions servers are amazing. I feel like a kid again. I'm having the time of my life. If you never played EQ back in the day you'll need to be very patient at first and ask for lots of help. This isn't a problem in EQ because people are generally very helpful. They'll give you money, gear, and buffs if they see you need it. I wouldn't suggest begging but you won't need to really. I highly suggest trying this or going back to the progession servers if you've been away for years like I have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021547127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 7217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1422, 'last_played': 1592233592}
review:
EverQuest (EQ) est un jeu de rôle en ligne massivement multijoueur sorti en mars 1999. L'idée originale est attribuée à Brad McQuaid, Steve Clover et Bill Trost. Pour jouer, il faut acheter le jeu puis souscrire un abonnement payant mensuel. Une version free to play d'EverQuest, ainsi qu'une version à prix réduit, sont disponibles depuis le 16 mars 2012 pour les 13 ans du jeu. Il a été développé par Verant Interactive et distribué par Sony Online Entertainment (SOE).

Le jeu prend place dans un univers imaginaire d'heroic fantasy en trois dimensions appelé Norrath, rappelant un univers médiéval parsemé d'objets magiques et de monstres fantastiques.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047030264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 555, 'last_played': 1581646363}
review: No game since has ever been as extreme as EverQuest. It forces you to work with others and play your role completely. It punishes you for acting recklessly, and forces you to enjoy the experience. Even 20 years later, this game stands out in a field of quick cash grabs or beautiful graphics. Coming back to this after nearly 15 years still elicits joy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976146897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1578503192}
review:
Everquest is, REALLY, the classic MMO: Lots of customization and systems, slow paced combat and leveling, good but unforgiven combat, great story, great gameplay and a great setting. Graphics are better than you imagine (since the game is pretty old) but, obviously, not great. Overall, a good experience imho.

PS: Although I would only recommend it to people who has a bit more free time, it's not a game that you'll master and enjoy if you play 2-4 hours a week, for example, since everything, in the game, takes a bit of time to accomplish.

review: Although I prefer classic EQ, despite its brutal learning curve and grinding, the "new EQ" is still a blast to play. Always something new to see and discover and the game is MUCH more solo/duo friendly for those inclined to explore on their own (like me much of the time). The free to play mechanics work very well for most players but a subscription will practically be required for hardcore raiding players. Give it a go if you've never tried it and want something a bit different from WoW.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972768400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1684382347}
review:
For me, the Original MMORPG. Every other game lacks something of feeling, of emotion, of necessity that EQ had. The difficulties and struggle made hunting skeletons as a level 3 worthwhile. You knew that you could sell them to a passing Necromancer or Shadow Knight. Banded armor meant something as a lowbie. Crafting had a purpose. 

Good gear set you apart. 

This game reeks of nostalgia. Enjoy it for what it is, best served with friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010059836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 29082, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6634, 'last_played': 1708697881}
review: Very fun game. Deep, complex, nostalgic, archaic. I hope EverQuest stays around for centuries. Better yet, I hope it becomes the first digital museum. As a monument for key advancements in not just Game Design, but for innovating the way we interact on the internet. I encourage everyone, both young old to give it a try. Even if it is just for the sake of learning where it came from and how far we came.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135397126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1706097840}

review: This Game is my #1 favorite of all time.  I have logged many days worth of hours playing Everquest.  The fun is the endless quests and adventures.  Developers are still coming up with new and challenging content for a game 20 years and running.  The community of folks I have played with over the years are true fans of the game and I have had many great friendships from the interactions.  Want a challenging MMO?  This is the way to go.  Hope you give EQ a try and See you in Norrath!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961360934', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 342720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188313, 'last_played': 1685605719}
review:
-PROGRESSION SERVERS- 
If you want to come back to this game or are a new player I recommend subscribing and playing on the newest progression server, whichever it may be at the time. Progression servers launch with non expansions available and slowly release a new expansion every few months so it is as if you are playing everquest back in the day waiting for the next expansion to come out. I have a blast every time I create new characters on progression servers and level alongside everyone else trying to level and farm items to sell, make some plat, buy better gear and so on. Progression servers do require an active membership which is the only drawback.

-LIVE SERVERS-
I can't speak much for live servers(non-progression), as I quit playing when they came out with "Autogrant"  alternate advancement (AA) points. If you have an active subscription on live and have auto grant enabled you automatically gain all AA points you need for your level up to a certain level. Imagine spending thousands of hours grinding AA points and feeling accomplished that you have 2800 aa's and then they release an expansion that automatically gives these points to everyone automatically for free when they level. Boy did that make me quit playing this game for a while. Also, like any gaming company, they release new content for a price and enable certain perks with the new content which makes you almost have to purchase the new content to stay relevant. I would stay away from the cashgrab of live servers and stick to progression. In my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148275732', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1666572751}

review: I was dragged into everquest by my brother. I was reluctant because it seemed boring. the gameplay is fairly mild unless you play melee. but i found the community and friendship from 90% of the players was top-tier friendly. I come and go occasionally and am always welcomed with open arms no matter what level i left at. people help each other and its a rare thing in the gaming community. im glad to have such good friends and strangers to help me succeed. if you want a friendly atmosphere this is the place for you. Im on Mangler and my name is fail if you ever wanna hang out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198444799164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 875556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560987, 'last_played': 1648473989}
review:
it's still way better than WoW and if you can find a decent casual guild, then you'll have a good time. 

The game is definitely geared towards boxing, but the F2P (Free To Play) is great and most of the pre-80's levels content is available (not limited to 'prestige' [paying] players).

The merc (mercenary) NPCs make boxing non-mandatory until after levels 105... but, it's a hard game to MOLO without being uber-outfitted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198828065106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1647808517}

review: I have played Everquest off and on since launch.  This game is and always will be my favorite MMO of all time because the newer MMOs (while they may be better graphically) do not hold a candle to the content and lore that this game has.  After 20 years of play, I can honestly say that if you have never played EQ before and can put the dated graphics aside, it will win you over.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971410594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1954, 'last_played': 1679901134}
review:
Everquest, is a venerable, but impressive game. The FTP feature is great, gives you the availability to play the game that many people, including myself, enjoyed for years. While I'm no EQ expert, the game is fun and has great old school, MMO, RPG elements.

If you're looking for a MMO classic to mess around in, EQ can easily be the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022931396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 281859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155225, 'last_played': 1704978720}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019236588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 851, 'last_played': 1571746841}
review:
Hadn't played this before. Veteran of Daoc and a host of other mmo's but I'd avoided investing any time in anything due to RL concerns. 

EQ is HUGE. Quite honestly, I'd say it's simply the largest game world I've ever seen. The graphics are pretty awful but the detail of the world and the variety of game mechanics make up for that. I'm only a few hours in but I'm enjoying the game, although the world does seem rather empty at times. Most players are well established and there's little low level stuff going on. It's a shame that there isn't more of a quest system to help you progress through the game and storyline... there might very well be one, but the sheer size of the game makes finding such difficult. 

Still, I'd recommend the game for anyone who wants a change from the more modern mmo's which can be rather depressing with their cash grabs and kiddy audiences.

review:
Der besondere flair von Everquest entsteht durch die Nostalgie sowie der Community. Klar gibt es in sachen Grafik , Gameplay und so ziemlich allen anderen Aspekten bessere Spiele... Doch ist dieses Spiel in der Gesamtheit und in der Harmonie der einzelnen Aspekte wirklich Top.

Man muss halt liebhaber sein und über die Grafik hinwegsehen. Wenn man dann einmal tief in der Spielstruktur drin ist und dann am besten sich einen frischen "Progression Server" angeschlossen hat . Dann kann man alle gefühle von damals nocheinmal neu erleben ... oder halt für die frischeren unter uns MMO´s sehen vor WoW ...

author: {'steamid': '76561197992805162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1567895135}
review:
So I love EQ. The games graphics are dated and thats 100% okay. The grind is exactly how i remember it. Some of the difficulty was removed and things like paths and maps make finding/finishing quests easy. i played 20 years ago and it was exactly how i remember...

except one glaring problem.

The game crashes. ALOT.

I got to level 11 in a couple of hours just doing the basic tutorial. Found me a nice group and was grinding away. Then the game crashes. with a runtime error. I load it up again and it goes to window mode, then crashes again. It does this another 5 times until it offers me to send a crash message to the developers. 

I really wanted to delve into the game again and feel upset I cant play. 

I will update my review if something changes, but as of now, don't let it break your gaming heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198253551769', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1554161045}
review:
One of the best MMO's you could possibly play in your life! I found this game at 23 years old, When the paid time locked servers Mangler and Selos launched for the 20th anniversary of Everquest. I have been hooked ever since playing on Mangler.

If you play Everquest, Please consider subscribing to Everquest. The reason why is because you can play on the many populated time locked servers for a more classic experience, where your playing with real people. The free live servers on the other hand are often dead and most people playing them are at max level, so in order to do the content you have to hire an npc mercenary to power you through the content which isn't that fun. 

10/10 experience easily!

PS, There is also a private server for Everquest called Project Quarm which is a lot better than the live servers for Everquest or even the time locked servers and accurately represents the game from 1999 if your looking for a more classic experience. Project Quarm also has a few thousand people playing and does not allow boxing which means it's all real people playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198296564267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 12011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11888, 'last_played': 1687098807}
review:
I played EverQuest for over ten years as a cleric. I went back to the new live progression server a month ago after taking more than a ten year break from EQ, and guess what I saw? The whole game is based around kronos now, a new in-game currency that lets you apply 30 days game time to your account. What really sucks is because of kronos all there is in the game now in pugs is greedy people ninja looting all your class spec. loot from you. You have to roll need against a bunch of greedy players in hopes of getting a spell or a piece of loot. It doesn't matter what it is, they're going to roll against you 99.9 percent of the time. And then you'll find groups that give loot away to players where you won't be able to need on loot at all, so it all really depends on who you're rolling with, but for me, that broke the game for me because all I mainly do is farm in pugs and now I can't progress my account in a meaningful way. I'm done. After losing a 55 spell on my cleric last night I quit the game. Now my guild is one cleric short for their upcoming raid on the eighth of this month and I'm not going back. The game is just full of krono farmers now and I'm not going to pay 15 bucks a month to become one of them, peace.

Day Break Games, you really know how to break games don't you? They break games, ironic, isn't it?

author: {'steamid': '76561198011079120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 27991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26036, 'last_played': 1605434064}
review:
Got dragged back into EQ after 18 years by a guildie who several accounts alive throughout the years. The sense of danger, and the steep learning curve is still there. Surprisingly I'm thoroughly enjoying my time back and the progression servers making grinding pretty much a non-issue compared to back in the day, I got to actually explore places I couldn't before and also enjoy the content that was released after I first left the game.

So far people I've newly met seems to be mature and fun loving, guess having a higher than average age or more old farts as I call it seem to change the environment for the better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153582707', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 23570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19687, 'last_played': 1674384757}
review:
The everquest dev team doesn't care. They literally allow griefing on a daily basis. Reports go unanswered for weeks, months and when you get a reply it's rarely helpful usually like "wut...who r u? Y U BUG ME." The game itself is interesting if dated beyond redemption, and at many times fascinating. The community is as ancient as the game, most of them are living in the past and refuse to change. They have this really old fashioned sense of online communication and tend to have this bizarre give and take mentality about everything.

Cliques are strong in this game and if you're new people will tend to troll you for asking basic questions, they will also refuse to believe you aren't an alt because nobody new would ever want to play everquest in their minds. For the most part they are right, if you didn't play this game 20 years ago don't even bother. If you're debating playing this game then just play Morrowind instead, it's the same but without the garbage community and drama that comes with online social interaction with random 40 year olds.

review: DO NOT >> I REPEAT DO NOT SUBSCRIBE THROUGH STEAM TO PLAY EVERQUEST  >> 3 days of lost payment no play on a TLP with both companies making me do all t he communication and screenshots back and forth and in the end a refund and no apology or recourse for my time or aggravation  . so if u plan to pay for everquest DO NOT USE STEAM>>>>>  I'm to the point id say just play free or emulated servers the way both companies handled my  help log..   at least 6-8 emails from each company back and forth.. and they both refused to talk to each other even though they had my money already .. steam has always been an example of how to do customer service this is sad.. and daybreak being a mmo provider .. u would think they would know what downtime from a game means to a player.. neither company  showed much care towards myself as a customer , just shifted blame several times     :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198040892359', 'num_games_owned': 3008, 'num_reviews': 368, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1557645605}
review:
[h1]*ding* I have gotten better at writing reviews 17[/h1]

I used to play years ago back when it was a sub service through SoE. What Daybreak has done to it is friggin nuts. While I think everyone should at least try EQ once in their lives, I'd recommend P99 over this one mostly because Daybreak tries to nickel and dime you to death. I mean, I understand it's FTP now, but so much is locked behind paywalls it's really not worth your time unless you're willing to pay out the ass. If it was purely a sub based game and everything was "unlocked" (like WoW) I'd pay $15/month to play this again. Even if you pay that for the Daybreak sub that still isn't enough for you not to need to spend more money. 

Sad really, because EQ is a great game. Granted, it's not 2002 anymore, but you still won't find anything quite like EQ.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053550575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 664, 'last_played': 1681069851}
review: Not a lot of interest content, a lot of repetitive quests and ugly outdated graphics, but I was willing to stick with it for a while just to see what a world that had lasted this long had to offer. Then I had to climb a ladder. I tried jumping, looking up, and my guy just refused to climb more than one or two steps. He would crouch, walk into the ladder. Who climbs a ladder by jumping? In over 10 years, why didn't any of the dev teams working on this game think it would be easier to just have someone click the ladder. I asked for help in chat and I tried following their advice except to turn levitate off because I didn't know how to do that and I shouldn't have to turn anything off to do a basic thing like climb a ladder. That ladder broke me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036096802', 'num_games_owned': 400, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1461216349}
review:
And now there are loot boxes, because of course there are.

Skip to the bolded italics if you're a returning player and just want to understand what EQ means by "free." If you're having trouble with a new account, remember to verify its email address!

I started playing EQ in 2000. I have at least a year and a half of real time spent in-game. My experience is positive, but that's partly because I started when it was the best show in town. I'm pretty sure I'll play it again, but I can't recommend it to new players. I've tried to get friends who have never played to join up over the past few years, and their responses to the initial experience have ranged from "nah" to "I'm bored sick." Every single one has quit. 

The problem is the new player experience. It's... stunted, even with friends (besides, anything is fun with friends). Most low level zones are empty of players, and some of the oldest are mostly empty space. Forming groups with other players for low level content takes time and effort, and you're not likely to run across other low level players once you've out-leveled the tutorial and the default starting city, which you should definitely use. Mid levels are a particularly isolating experience, since at that point you've outlasted other newbies and most people's alts are either low level or high level.

And goodness forbid you choose the "wrong" class to level. Unless you run multiple accounts, you're going to have a really dull time with some classes for the first 70-75 levels because their shiny stuff and even a lot of basic modern functions were added late in the game's history and never given effective low-level versions, so for some classes you mostly just stand near an enemy, waiting for it to die of auto-attacks. Brilliant.

Similarly, some classes can be hard to level by yourself even with a mercenary to help, or just hard to play effectively. And while there are shortcuts you can take and guides you can follow to make a lot of this better, it's not fun to have to master navigating the community, online info sites, and even the game's system folder (for adding map packs, a practical necessity) just to function well enough.

Plus, for all that you can jazz them up and make them work for you, the default UI is functional but clunky and the controls are pretty jank. And the community can be a bit... prickly. I mean that in the kindest way I can say it, but it's not for everyone.

Sadly, EverQuest hasn't kept up with the times. There are smarter, more polished experiences out there, with much better new player experiences, even without sacrificing depth of lore and breadth of content.



[b][i]If you've somehow made it this far and still want to play the game,[/i][/b] you have two meaningful choices. Please note that in either case, you will automatically gain all but the last couple of expansions for free. Good deal, right? When you reach level 100+, consider buying the latest expansion to unlock all current content. Previous expansion(s) included.


1) Play on any server with a subscription. Or at least, subscribe when you reach level 70+.

EverQuest's free model was never meant to last through high level content. Without a subscription, you can't really function much beyond chatting at high levels--you'll be locked out of a lot of alternate advancement points, higher-ranked versions of spells, strong mercenary companions, and even a lot of high level equipment. Think of it like World of Warcraft's max level 20 free trial but with chat enabled.


2) Play on the Test server without a subscription (you'll have to change the game version to Test in your launcher settings). 

Test is a slightly different game version where you get most of the benefits of a subscription (minus the monthly free microtransaction currency) for free. Your old characters can be /testcopy 'd to Test at no risk. Your characters on Test won't be wiped, and bugs are generally not game-breaking. The cherry on top is always-on double experience gains. The community is small and short on raiding, but extremely casual-friendly, which is probably what you're looking for if you want to play a game for free.

Thanks for reading! If you've struggled to get into EQ yourself or you've had any luck getting new people into the game, I'd love to hear from you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049253886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1558999724}
review:
Avoid.
 
I downloaded this "free to play" game only to discover you need a membership to play on their nostalgia server (which is the only reason people like me would be interested in this 20 year old game). That's fine, since "free" doesn't mean free anymore, and so I was willing to pay for a month or so to relive some old gaming experiences...

The Daybreak website must be run on hamsters on wheels, because each page I tried to navigate through took several minutes to load. I finally go to their membership page, and the only option I was given was an "all access" pass for $15 a month. Since I was only interested in playing Everquest again, I did not want to pay $15 for "all access" to a bunch of their games which, frankly, suck. I wanted to see if they had a lower tier option as sometimes they hide those to force you to pay more than you have to, and so I tried to contact customer service:
 
I clicked on the link on their website, and even though I was already logged into their website, and even though their "support" page was part of this website, it asked me to log in again (and the login procedure on their website is a joke: it takes forever to load, and they make you do a Rorschach test of "click all the boxes with streetlights or storefronts").
 
...So after spending several minutes logging in again I tried to ask my question--it told me before I could ask a question I had to verify my email address even though they had already verified it when I made the account. I clicked on "verify account", and then they said they'd email me a link with a secret question. That email of course never came.
 
My E-trade account has less stringent security measures. Either Daybreak's website was designed by a troupe of nose-picking monkeys, or they just want to set up so many hoops you have to jump through that you'll give up trying to contact customer support and then they won't have to hire someone for that position.

Needless to say, I didn't want to try this game so much as to deal with their incompetence, so I said eff it. I was annoyed enough to write this review however. If a company can't get something as basic as a website right, I don't want to deal with everything else they've messed up.
 
The prognosis: Avoid this company and all of their games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991498981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 127181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2098, 'playtime_at_review': 49309, 'last_played': 1711149058}
review:
Edit: Still here still playing, new TLP severs still coming out and helping to keep the game refreshed. They are still working on the game and it is far from dead. 

After 19 years of playing it I still find myself coming back from time to time. While it has changed and much has not been well received I find it still fun to play though again and again exploring zones I haven't seen in years with class combinations I haven't done before. If you want more old school, some of the Progression servers can hit the spot ( Important note: the farmers are in mass on what ever is the newest servers so that can be a problem in mid and late game). After all that they have servers still active enough to keep groups forming and even raids on quite a few servers. All in all it is still a great game and I hope to repeat my logging in to play for 6 months or so for another 10 years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049556612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2793, 'last_played': 1554775412}
review:
I spent the first five hours arranging the game's multitude of user interface windows and configuring game settings. Then I was able to begin the tutorial, where I have chosen to remain as long as I can to grind loot to sell to the merchant NPC for large amounts of game currency, which I then use to level up trade skills. Unfortunately, there are graphics impediments to gameplay (frames skip in a way I have not seen in other games, where you cannot look in a certain direction, but instead, the camera jumps over the direction... it's badly designed). If you like rolling dice to see if you can do anything in a game, and if you like tedious movement controls which make you work on the keyboard to do repetitive tasks, and if you like other stupid annoyances, then this game is for you! Have fun with that! *smile* And of course, by leveling up, I mean spending minutes walking from one place to another or running around in what is essentially a field or forest arena, and then sitting and waiting for long periods of time as your character stands there and crafts (or fails to craft, depending upon the roll of the dice) items.

Basically, the game is bloated with content, while the gameplay itself is tragically unrevised.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973079535', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 87504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1692229969}
review: My family started out our serious gaming together around 2000 with this game. At that time, we had the basic dial up AOL internet setup, and ended up with 3-5 phone lines for our various computers to play. The level of challenging, interactive, team coop setups built into this game I haven't found in the various MMO games since that time. We have tried a LOT of different games, BETA, and release, but in the end there hasn't been a game that made me really want to buckle down, help out a guildmate, or improve my overall skills in a game. I keep looking for another game like this, but in the end, I don't think I will find it's equal. I still come back to it now and then, but the graphics are not up to par with what is available 2018.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976644459', 'num_games_owned': 889, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 62639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10514, 'last_played': 1704675355}
review:
In short, despite its age and poor graphics by today's standards, there is a sense of accomplishment and community you get from Everquest that is not present in more modern games.

The real sense of a living, breathing world that you're just a part of has been given up for the "amusement park" model and probably isn't coming back anytime soon.

So I recommend everyone tries this game at least once. Treat it like D&D and ignore the graphics and you might just find a wonderful experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975391548', 'num_games_owned': 70, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1442070764}
review:
I played this from 1999 to 2004, 5 years, until the day World of Warcraft came out. At that point WoW was all I played until I quit playing MMOs altogether. I loved MMOs but none can ever match the original EverQuest and first two expansions.  EQ had something that kept people playing and I think what it was primarily was that its original game mechanics not only forced people to be social, but it made the MMO very challenging albiet frustrating challenges at times. I don't know that anyone will ever recapture what the first MMO had, but I wish someone would carry the torch and recreate the original EQ with the most modern graphics and user interface.  Everything else would be the same as it was:

1. The world seemed so big because getting around meant traveling by foot or by boat, unless you made a friend who could teleport to specific locations.
2. Dying meant having to find your corpse, naked, so you could get your stuff back. It wasn't easy.
3. Finding a group meant talking in chat and making friends.
4. You could not kill most things without at least one other partner.
5. Healing and buffs were powerful and appreciated.
6. Only 8 spells could be memorized at any given time.
7. Classes were distinct and unique with little overlap.
8. Servers had fairly small populations that got to know each other over time.
9. Rare spawns, rare items, these meant negotiating and sharing with others.
10. If there was a grind, it wasn't noticeable, because you were never alone.

review: This game in 2018 is quite different than it was in 1999. You'll have to subscribe to join special legacy servers that attempt to recreate the magic of vanilla EQ while slowly progressing through each expansion over a set period of time. Still fun to play for free for a month or two for nostalgia.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968126518', 'num_games_owned': 1458, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1547929106}
review: The best mmo I have ever played,(Several thousand hours played off Steam). Can be hard for new players to get into now due to it's age and diminished server populations but just ask for help in the chat channels and try to find a helpful guild to help you as you learn. It is definitely the most rewarding of all mmo's I have played, and while it has changed a lot and has had some of the more severe elements toned down, it is still one of the most challenging mmo's out there but well worth the effort imo.

review:
I played this game when it came out in 1999. It was my very first MMORPG. I had friends that played it as well. It is probably one of my favorite games of all time. I stopped playing in 2004 and recently picked it back up. It was a very nostalgic trip down memory lane. 

Pros: Huge in game world to explore with regular content releases. Vigorous and active player base (may vary by server). Always something to do.

Cons: Graphics are very dated. UI is not intuitive for the new and uninitiated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026760705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1608858570}
review:
아직도 플레이하는 올드비입니다. 

라이브서버와 다르게 프로그레스(서비스) 서버가 생겨 오리지날부터->다음확팩이 몇달(보통3달)에 걸처 천천히 열리는 서비스서버입니다.

유료결제를 하지않으면 게임을 하지못하지만, 플레이하는 한국분들은 아직 남아있습니다.

다만 아주 어렵고 또 어렵습니다 쉬운게임은아닙니다. 게다가. 영어를 사용해야됩니다.

그럼에도 불구하고 게임을 즐기는 분들이 아직남아있습니다. 

라이브서버에 몇분 프로그래스 서버에 몇분남아있습니다.

관심있으시면 네이버까페 eqlife 찾아 보세요 나름 활성화되어있습니다. 

많은 분들이 같이 하는건 아니지만 즐기기엔 부족하지 않네요.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978754063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 18329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3790, 'last_played': 1698791256}
review:
I played EQ back in the day and it does my heart good to see it still alive, even if it isn't as populated as it should be. EverQuest, hence forth refered to as EQ, is beautiful even with it's dated graphics, brilliantly written, and a challenge.  EQ emphasises exploration by giving the task of finding quests to the player, rather than leading players to quests (thus removing the need to explore). 

EQ, even after nearly 20 years, is still a 10 out of 10. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a challenge, and a game with a well written story and lore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106160348', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1538148975}
review:
Dieses Spiel hat mich viele Nächte wach gehalten und Jahre in anspruch genommen...

Ganze Ordner mit Rezepturen und Zaubersprüchen wurden angelegt - 15/20 Jahre her ! Es fanden sogar RL Treffen mit der Gilde statt.

Leider nur noch auf Englisch verfügbar. Und da leider sehr Textlastig und mangelnde Zeit nix mehr für mich heutzutage.

Aber trotzdem Dauemn hoch - Das Game war für eines der ersten MMORPG das geilste, noch vor WoW aufgrund der Spieltiefe, den ausgeklügelten Quests und die unendlichen Entdeckungen in der Welt als auch im Forschen die man machen konnte ! - Ein Meisterwerk !

author: {'steamid': '76561198044115335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1535286901}
review:
I will start with this: I beta tested this game. I played this for YEARS before it ported to Steam. I have *thousands* of hours of play time. It changed a LOT over the years.

Why am I recommending an outdated and archaic game?

That's easy - because this was one of the games that really started it all. Preceded by only Ultima Online and before that text based MOOs, MUDs, and MUSHes.

You don't play a game like this for the graphics - they were top for their day, they're painfully dated now. You play this for nostalgia. You play this for a real challenge and an arseload of content. You play this to understand what us old geezerly gamers are talking about when we say "back in our day..."

If you want to experience an 80-person raid WITHOUT VOICE CHAT? You want to understand what guild dynamics really means? You can still get a taste of it here. Of course, technology has advanced - and gone are the days of 8 hour raids and perfectly timed text macros... but in this game you'll get a taste of what it's like to navigate without a map - having to *memorize* your entire game world. And yes, you can simply fire up Vent or Discord and rock on. But, it's fun to really go full nostalgia.

You'll actually have to do the legwork yourself (provided you don't wimp out and go for Google). In the end - this is a game best played for nostalgia. To rediscover the love of gaming not for graphics - but for CONTENT. It's a lot to choke down if you're the kind of gamer that grew up on games you could max out your levels on (eg: WoW) in a week, or had everything handed to you - or are all flash and pomp and beatable in a week or less...

However, if you're craving a challenge with a great deal of lore... and learning to run like heck for boats... and discovering that Clerics actually CAN be bum kickin', plate wearin', mace weildin', raid machines - then look no further. If you're looking for pretty and having everything handed to you without any effort at all (save maybe a few hours of gamplay), then go play WoW.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003308890', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 295, 'playtime_forever': 6199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1548970018}
review: Everquest has been my original classic game that led me to love MMO's i have played this game and taken breaks since BETA, been in the best guilds on the server and things have changed over the years, some great changes some not so good.  I have the original goxes and cds from most of the expansions before it went digital and remember standing in line for hours just to get the new releases.  The recent Ring of Scale expansion to me is a huge disappointment and was just laziness on the parts of the devs to rename zones the same as newbiew zones and is beyond conusing to playes and for a game of this caliber just not acceptable.  That said the overall concept of this game has remained strong for years, yes the player base has dropped but the quality of the people still in game is grea and i still love to play and raid on this game and all these years later still recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065836072', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 14943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11916, 'last_played': 1589644904}
review:
Very old MMO. The current playing population are naturally all veterans. Unless you're a returning player (if you are, I'm constantly hearing,"I quit in xx and just got back." So, they're very welcoming. Of new and returning players really, just hardly any new players. 

Graphics are obviously severely dated but that's to be expected. Gameplay is MMO standard experience. That's because this was THE standard before WoW. 

If you're looking for something dated but still a potential gem with the right group of friends then I'd recommend this game. Otherwise, not so much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146124353', 'num_games_owned': 234, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 98518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13014, 'last_played': 1652232365}
review:
Been playing EverQuest since 2000. I was only 5 when I started, but still have fond memories of drowning in the well behind the fake wall in Qeynos. This game made up a HUGE part of my childhood. I've made several friends while playing, many of whom even became my friends outside of the game.

I have something like 12,000 hours played at this point, with probably another few thousand to come. At one point I was a guild/raid leader, but most of the time that I've spent playing was pretty casual overall. Now I'm at a point in my life where I can't really lead raids or a guild effectively due to time constraints, but even if I just want to solo or maybe join a casual guild, I have plenty of fun doing that.

While I prefer the way the game used to be in its early days, as most people who have played it extensively do, I've still thoroughly enjoyed it up to this day. Of course not every expansion is going to be the greatest, but I legitimately enjoy about 21 of the 27 that exist right now. On another note, progression and time-locked servers allow us to go back and experience the older content we loved so much, even if it's still not quite the same feeling that we used to get years ago.

author: {'steamid': '76561198299552166', 'num_games_owned': 11, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1526318317}
review:
Jeu vraiment très en avance pour son époque. Je comprends qu'il y ait des gens qui y ont passés des milliers d'heures.
On voit tout de suite d'où WoW à tiré son inspiration. (Blibli s'est VRAIMENT pas foulé...)

avantages:
-univers enchanteur pour l'époque.
-des mécaniques de jeu fondatrices du genre.
-un "lore" interessant s'y on s'y attarde.
-un aspect plus communautaire que les MMORPG d'aujourd'hui.
-énormément de choses à faire (crafting, leveler, découverte...).
-des races "non humaines" appréciables (ce qui se fait rare de nos jours...).

inconvénients:
-le jeu qui nous pousse à l'abonnement dès la PREMIERE seconde en jeu.
-mécaniques de jeu dépassées (caméra, animations, poids de l'équipement?!, des zones qui manquent littéralement de map pour se diriger...etc) .
-le GRIND.
-l'interface, même si elle à été revue, est quand même obsolète.
-LE GRIND.
-le taux de "miss" des armes à bas level inacceptable.
-LE GRIND pour quasiment tout les aspects du jeu!
-les mercenaires, bonne idée au départ, font que chacun joue un peu dans son coin au final.

Conclusion:
Ce jeu est très bon pour se faire une idée de ce qui se faisait en 1999: une excellente expérience dans un très bon univers. Parfait aussi pour les mazos du GRIND à outrance où les zombies qui ont choisi de vivre comme option.
Pour les autres, passez votre chemin. Si vous voulez vous amuser, les MMORPG actuels font TOUT mieux.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973554597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 10287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1658566984}
review:
Game is broken again. Forums have tons of posts about the game freezing with a black screen after sever selection. Steer clear.

EDIT:
Fix on the forums I found originally posted by Wulfhere.

HardwareTnL=TRUE
VertexShaders=1
1xPixelShaders=0
14PixelShaders=0
20PixelShaders=1

^I did this and deleted all character and server specific .ini files in the same folder. Good luck. Leaving my review negative because this has happened multiple times and it should not ever happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962332788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1578155506}
review:
To be clear, I am reviewing Daybreak's EQ and not SOE and certainly not Verant's EQ (or even p99, in that fact).

The game is essentially 80% cash shop. I'm so flooded with cash shop everything, I don't even recognize the game anymore. Because you can also get titles, illusions, ornaments (changes looks), and even auras with cash and minimal effort, it takes away individuality and "cool factors". Spent 200 hours to get a super cool illusion? Doesn't matter. Pay $5 and you can get an even cooler illusion, like turn into a harpy or monster, rendering any hard-earned items useless.

Daybreaker of Games also killed EverQuest: Next and laid off the people that made EQ.... EQ.

Used to be my favorite game of all time. I even liked SOE's early take on it (didn't love it, but it was still wonderful). However, Daybreak's EQ is depressingly bad. On the bright side, I can finally quit!

Don't judge the [b]Steam[/b] time played, I assure you I'm a '99 vet of Rallos Zek, then later P99 Red

author: {'steamid': '76561197999996475', 'num_games_owned': 462, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1579741040}
review:
It had been quite some time since I'd played Everquest when I reluctantly downloaded it from Steam in hopes to gain a fraction of nostalgia to sate my growing need for something enjoyable to play.

Think of Everquest as the original MMORPG, because that's essentially what it is. It's a clunky three dimensional romp through a rather large and colorful world filled with all sorts of things to stab repeatedly like a crack-addicted rogue looking for high on the body of a recently deceased toad.

That being said, this isn't quite the same game I recall. The overall game play has remained exactly what it was when I played in the days of yore, but with a twist. The game has become largely free-to-play, lending to an optional subscription model. What isn't explicitly stated is that the F2P access is stunted by the sheer absence of players on any given part of the map. Finding a player on an F2P server is about as easy to do as extracting a decaying tooth from a live bear without tranquilizing it first.

The secondary problem lies with a fact that burns at the very core of my disheveled heart: this game now has loot boxes. Not only does that leave a sour taste in my mouth, but it also cheapens the memories I had of killing the same enemies repeatedly in hopes of getting a drop that might actually be beneficial. Loot boxes might seem desirable to a naive nubile player who hasn't been around the block yet, but for a battle-hardened cynic like myself it just reminds me of how much the gaming world has gone to hell in the last decade.

That being said, if you're willing to overlook these fatal flaws or are willing to pay for the subscription, it's certainly worth your while, at least until whatever your next fancy happens to come off early-access as a fully developed game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110052201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 16621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5780, 'last_played': 1672115110}
review:
Game is awful, and this is coming from a guy who played it hardcore 12 years ago.
Clunky
Poor design
Classic EQ ( if you start on a new server ) is horrible.
Old school grind that is so boring.
Community is all about trading shop cash items for plats, new players will struggle... no one buys spiderling silk anymore ;)
Gear is whack ( unless you play on older server thats had all the rebalancing then its ok )
You will struggle to find groups, soloing on classic is a waste of time.
Long story short:
Old game
Boring
Classic version sucks
Community limited, either few old school helpful players, or bunch of WoW barren chat trolls.
Spend most of your time /00C LFG
Bored
Good bye.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095313873', 'num_games_owned': 17, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1525687164}
review:
我们 100多万个中国玩家期待EQ回归

这款游戏当初颠覆了世界的认知，被评为全球最好的网络游戏，可惜当时要求配置很高，很多国人都没体验到游戏的乐趣，10几个种族，10几个职业，上千种法术，没玩过此游戏的，简直是终身的遗憾，记得此游戏出来几年后，WOW抄袭了此游戏的10分之一内容，并且把游戏简单化，此举大获成功，WOW成为大众所能接受的游戏产物。
  WOW从公测开始到现在，我每年都会花时间进去体验。游戏虽然很棒，但WOW给我的感觉依然无法和此游戏相提并论。那感觉简直无法用语言来形容WOW到底差在哪里。简单来说，WOW可以无脑玩，上手容易，而EQ，上手十分困难，新手跑地图都困难。。
  就是因为上手困难，玩家不愿意烧脑的去看文字学习游戏，从而导致玩家宁可玩传奇，也不愿意碰这款世界公认的顶级游戏，国服记得运行了1年多就关闭了。
 最后补充一句，给我中文，我立刻删除魔兽世界，我需要再次和你相遇。

author: {'steamid': '76561198175864514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 33019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22148, 'last_played': 1708353771}
review:
This is a good game, it has plenty of content; including many quests, spells, classes, dungeons, raids, and lots of adventure. However, I think this game can be very punishing to new players as you have to go and find the right quests and I find that very taxing on time just because of the huge amount of trial and error in figureing out how to complete these quests. This is both a good thing and a bad thing in most cases. However the reason I like this game so much is the fact it has so much content to explore. Overall I would recommend this game to other people; it is a game that changed my perspective on all mmo games in a good way.
The only thing I would say is nagitive besides the questing is the fact that I find it difficult to level between certain level ranges such as from 50 all the way to max. The reason why is because not many people play between those levels and so I have to solo everything even with the help of mercenaries it is still difficult. I can only play on certain realms being a silver player and I think this is a drawback of the game iteself in my own personal opinion.
Overall like I said before this is a good starter mmo game and I would recommend it to people if I could to help increase player base on the realms.

author: {'steamid': '76561198330983530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2309, 'last_played': 1569026609}
review:
When I started back in 1999 this was a great game, everyone helped each other and it was fun.
Now the EQ community at least on Luclin-Strom server has become trash. They all want to be number 1, they backstab, lie, spread false rumors even in their own guild. Lots of whinny sniveling cowards, bottom of the barrel players now. Some of the people are cool, but it has become trash.
Daybreak people arent the brightest people around either. They gear everything towards the top guilds and people in lower guilds or solo players have no chance to advance anymore.
Back in the day I would have recommended it, but now, I would recommend this game to anyone. It has become
a game for crybabies. They even made it easier that they have to hold your hand and these idiot players still complain its to hard to play.
So if you ever wanted to play Everquest, either use a time machine or play something newer. Its just going to get worse as long as the developers keep their heads up the asses of the top guilds.
Even the Leaders and officers just use their members to get what they want and dont care about their members, and the idiots still follow them.
