author: {'steamid': '76561197983970175', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 27582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16373, 'last_played': 1609548979}
review:
I spent some time on a live server and on a progression server.  
Live (Vox)-
Got two characters to level 40 something fairly quickly.  Gear drops like an ARPG, makes it mean less when something drops.  Easy mode with mercs, group play is all but non-exsisting. It was a fun little theme park ride through Crescent Reach zone, doing quests, amassing wealth, collecting gear.  Then I realized it wasn't challenging and it was very single-player.  So I decided to join Agnar progression server, for a more authentic EQ experience. 

Progression (Agnar)-
Leveled a warrior to 48.  It took a great deal more time to level up than on the live server.  It felt like I was making progress at a decent rate.  I explored some neat zones with some awesome enemies.  Spent a great deal of time in camps with full groups to take on enemies because it was REQUIRED to do so.  This was a good thing.  Until you can't find a group.  Until you have to fight/invis your way through an entire dungeon to get to the camp spot.  Until someone dies and they are practically lost to the group.  
After spending so much time grinding mobs in various different camps I realized that it was the same thing over and over again. I finally reached a massive dungeon zone referred to as "Velks".  This place was huge, confusing, dangerous, and I was excited to finally be here. I spent some time at the enterence of the zone in a camp killing spiders.  Hours.  I finally leveled up enough to move to a more forward camp of the zone.  After navigating this annoying slippery ledged zone, I reached my new camp, finally, a change of scenery at least!  Alas, I was expected to kill more spiders.  I did the math after slaying one of these enemies:

1% XP towards next level per one spider killed.
130 seconds spent killing each spider.
216 minutes per level.
At least 5 more levels before I change camps.

I'm sorry, but this game is not fun.  It may have been for it's time, but this mechanic and obvious time sink, just isn't worth it. You do the same thing, every fight, every camp, every zone.  Group composition doesn't change the flow or tactics.  There is nothing different from killing frogs in Uguk to killing spiders in Velks.  
Tank aggros mob. 
CC role CCs other mobs.
Team damages main mob. 
Healer heals team.
Mob dies.
Grab the next mob.
Until you just can't do it anymore and go play a different game, with more interesting mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965281582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 679920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 284, 'playtime_at_review': 213258, 'last_played': 1710868859}

Everquest is an MMO with a lot of content and is also free to play.

Without the tutorial, I would imagine it is difficult for a new player.  The graphics are older, but with the revamps it is not a big deal.

I would get this game because it is one the best MMOs that I have ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972271775', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1611461376}
review:
Just too old/dated. Controls are clumsy, and robotic. graphics are simply obsolete.  My memory is much more pleasant than this really is. Quite honestly I watched You-Tube videos that I found more entertaining than Everquest is currently. 
Two minutes in Daybreak is slamming popups, I am still trying to figure out which of the five windows I need to click. Ran straight out looking for signs of life.... nothing. Chat... nothing. On life support I suppose. 
 Honestly it's time for Daybreak to get off their lazy ***es and reboot this. Quit trying to milk this eighteen year old cow, the milk is sour. I understand EQ Next was just not doable, but as a player, neither is this. quit sponging what is left of your playerbase and create something worthy of a new playerbase. Please, no more Landmarks. Anyway toodles.

review:
the last time I actively played this game was in 2011. The WORST thing they ever done with the game is the free to play option which if you had raid gear was to take away gear and bags and make it unusable that people had for there toons before the free to play came into the game. A person that had items on there toons BEFORE it turned free to play should STILL have access and able to use those items, not to take items off there toons and try to force a "all access" membership down there throat just to get there vanished items back.... that is absolute bull sh*te crap thing to do. I was a hard core EQ player from the day the game out until 2011. 

I would have recommended this game pre-2012 but now ABSOLUTELY NOT. horrible game now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961374716', 'num_games_owned': 69, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1616467354}
review:
#Xegony for life!

REMEMBER KIZAROKO MUZAMOTO!!! 72 Druid!

This game. I played this back in the 90's on my 1st account. I didn't like it at first, and my ex wanted to keep the old account, So I was like, okay take it! Yeh, I did share the account with her and She had her Calashar Du'Shadikan. For me?  I was done with EQ, because of Drama on Cazic Thrull and other issues. 

BUT! I came back a year later around 2000. Bought the CD's again and reinstalled. This was back when Sony Entertainment owned EQ. So I rerolled my Character on a TOTALLY new account. Started to fall in Love with EQ! This was on Xegony. I feel into the Evercrack life with Raids and leveling. This game was just.. SO much fun. 

Level 72 Druid Kizaroko Muzamoto Wood Elf.
Level 55 Barbarian Gundark Strumguard. 

I came back to the game just recently and I notice all of my character were gone. Just gone.. No more. SOOO those days are over for me.

But for you players who want the taste of old school MMORPG. Everquest! Give it a try and enjoy! Give you a chance to play a game that was the GRANDFATHER of all the MMO's we play today.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981781173', 'num_games_owned': 758, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 17721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16538, 'last_played': 1525405530}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979935608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 7308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4808, 'last_played': 1697020177}
review:
I've been playing this game for nearly 20 years, and I always come back to Live or Project 1999 (emu server up to Velious xpac, my favorite era).

Seriously... it is one of the best MMORPGs ever created, if not the best.

I really cannot recommend this game enough, even to younger players, as long as you can get past the dated graphics.

It's an incredible, challenging, and immersive experience, though I personally prefer their progression servers or P99, current EQ is still pretty great.

It's a little hand-holdy on live these days, so it's not /quite/ as sandbox as it used to be (still more than most games though), but on the progression servers, or P99 especially, it's a challenging, hardcore experience.

Pantheon can't come soon enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049653949', 'num_games_owned': 1305, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1669994255}
review: I played this game from the ages of about 10 until about 23 on and off. I've been unable to really get back into it ever since it became free to play and pay to win...Also, parenthood. I spent my younger years on Seventh Hammer and Erollisi Marr and played mostly on Zek later. Real world money has become too important in this game and that disgusts me. Tutorial zones replacing starting cities disgusts me. However, I figure that the player base has shrunk over the years and that these and a lot of other changes were out of necessity. For the sake of nostalgia, for the many years of my life that were dominated by this game, I will wholeheartedly recommend it. It is a legend, the elderly despot of MMOs.

review: Still the best game i have ever played, never touched the steam version but I still have the original disks including the exspanstions.  When i think if the best times i had playing a game then its with Everquest, so many found memeries of good times and lost friendships, my longest playing char logged 10k hours alone and i had 32 chars in all, this to me was my gaming heaven, not so much now as time moves on and standards change like all things.  All i can say is thank you Everquest for the wonderful times I had.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995286614', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4167, 'last_played': 1683837139}
review: Just a word to the wise, this game is extremely dated. Yes, it is f2p, so I wouldn't expect them to roll out a red carpet for you if you don't subscribe. But, in all honestly, I would recommend the game for a trip down nostalgia lane- though I'd recommend staying out of the freeport area, as they've been revamped- though they are aesthetically better than before, it drastically saps the nostalgia factor- better to level in the Qeynos/Halas regions, as those will be where the nostalgia can come to life. I'd recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenge, who is willing to work through the grind. However, it is not very casual-friendly and, yep, it is extremely grindy. I honestly play it solely for the nostalgia, so if you were looking for an MMO that pays off for time invested, it may not be for you, though, don't let that completely discourage you from trying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964126401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1302, 'last_played': 1500685061}
review: I recently starting playing this game again. At first it was a fun blast from the past. Then I hit the 250 AA limit. That's where the difference between so-called gold players (paying players) and free players begins to show itself. With every level after that point the gap between paying and free players gets bigger and the content becomes increasingly less enjoyable for free players. At the highest levels this difference becomes so large that it would take dozens of free players to do what one single paying player can do. Everquest has become the worst kind of pay to win. Even compared to other pay to win games Everquest is bad. The difference between a free and paying player is the difference between night and day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198278259537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3663, 'last_played': 1511465956}
review: My computer could barely this in highschool. That was 17 years ago. For me finally getting to really immerse myself in the higher level content that was laughably graphic-intensive back in the 90s has really been a lot of fun. Sure its dated, sure its slow paced, sure its deep and not hand holding, but for an old gamer like me its like finally being able to finish a book . the one downside is the game world is virtually empty but I play on a pvp server and use the mercs so i dont really care about parties . Thank you for reviving this gem from the past.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010200663', 'num_games_owned': 312, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1499765752}
review:
I couldn't get into this game. By that, I mean, I couldn't figure out how to actually interact with the world.

The lack of an options screen before I created my character was annoying. The way names flash above characters' heads when you target them, and it was usually my own character's name doing that, is annoying.

The user interface is horrible, but then, I guess that's part of the MMORPG genre (or it is NOW, thanks to the unbelievable influence of this game?)

The thing that really irritated me is the way quests and interacting with NPCs seem to work. I don't want to have to interact with the chat window, and if I -have- to interact with the chat window to start quests and stuff, I want what I need to do to be clear, and if what I need to do isn't clear, I would at least like something to happen when I do the wrong thing.

Oh, also, I resent that I have to type words to get my thumbs down to register.

Really, I just want Steam to not recommend this game, or games like it, to me anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198333728471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 13415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12710, 'last_played': 1596171524}
review:
This game is one of the best mmo's of all time. I started playing this during the time that commonlands was the main spot for trading. 

EQ is pure old school, there is none of that "x" marks the spot on the map just to see where the next objective is. 

The only con so far is the Free to Play restrictions, which means you will have a hard time without that trustworthy J5 merc and not being able to use rank 2 or higher spells, this also includes not maxing up to level 110 and getting the aa's

But you can either pay a monthy gold membership if you are on a live server or switch to the test server where you get the gold perks for free.

This game has 25 expansions which = to piles and piles of content to keep you happy. Loads of quests and missions.

The players on this game are really nice, people is always helpful in answering questions in the public chat, plenty of wizards and druids around as well, they will be happy to port you anywhere and grouping is never an issue, just remember you cannot be too high of a level to group with someone, otherwise the other party will not get the exp. 

Xegony-Druzzil Ro, Firiona Vie & Test Servers

Skyelah, Lv. 110 Female Drakkin Mage

author: {'steamid': '76561198024975458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 19503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14536, 'last_played': 1504833417}
review:
Great old school MMO.
Cash shop is pretty much cosmetic and some bag type stuff, not pay to win at all.
If you pay you can choose from an updated tutorial, more modern version or join a progression server for a more vanilla old school experience.
I played this back from 1999-2006, now that its on Steam, I'm back and loving it all over again.
Highly recommend if you like a truly challanging MMO with the best risk vs reward (IMO) going in MMO's today.

review: Played ever since the 1999 release with my dad. For my 8th birthday he let me make a character on his account, I will never forget how I tried to name him after my best friend Tyler but mispelt and made my name "Tyer". Two hours in, not knowing what I was doing I was gifted a huge axe from a nice community member, I wish I knew what I was doing back then. Oh well, got back into it and loving every minute, AMAZING game and will forever back this game up by saying it was the game that got me into games, thank you SOE.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049558119', 'num_games_owned': 2214, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 4059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3698, 'last_played': 1590974929}
review: EverQuest was my first MMO and I have spent literal years of my life playing it. However nostalgia is a place to which you can never return. EQ in its current state is a dead game with no sign of returning a pulse. I could write pages on how this game could be returned to glory but suffice it to say that your time would be better spent elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109745577', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 8083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3886, 'last_played': 1655525015}
review:
The Free to Play restrictions are some of the most annoying in an ostensibly f2p mmo, but there's just something about Everquest that remains one of the most entertaining games in its genre.

Everquest is Old School. There's no magic arrow pointing to your next objective. Quest-givers don't mark locations on your map. There's no fast travel outside of a handful of rare spells for wizards. Skills increase by being used. EVERYTHING can murder you solo. But there's a role for every class, and you won't find wizards tanking hits to the chin. If you're tired of themepark mmo's holding your hand and guiding you safely through Mr. Frog's Wild Ride, this might be your game. It's esoteric as fvck. What resources/guides remain online are confused by the many updates to the game, and low player populations mean that it's likely not going to get better. If you want to learn crafting, you're going to have to act like a real student and spend a few hours searching archives and hunting down lost manuscripts just get your feet wet.

Overall, if you're looking for something challenging and old school and can put up with some big f2p annoyances, give the granddaddy of mmorpgs a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008978004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 25737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14955, 'last_played': 1671370866}

Not worth paying to play here. Customer service is nonexistent, 15 days with a problem and I can't get my ticket answered. There is no live chat. author: {'steamid': '76561198093777167', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 137553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 331, 'playtime_at_review': 8708, 'last_played': 1711029419}
review:
Well, i'm having fun with it and i'm not sure why there are so many negative reviews but I have missed a lot.

I started playing in March of 1999 as a dark elf magician. I got up to level 36 and then made a dark elf necromancer instead and played dark elf necromancers for the rest of my EQ time.

I remember Kunark and Velious, I mostly ignored Luclin and then I quit in the Planes of Power era, this was around 2004. I came back for a month in 2008 but the game had changed so much that I did not stay.

I came back in March of 2017 because I saw a FB advertisement about a free boost to 85 and I saw that EQ was free to play on Steam.

I installed EQ and logged onto my level 64 necromancer for the first time in almost 10 years and was a bit overwhelmed with everything. It took me some time to get used to the user interface and all of the different windows, I boosted to 85 which also gave me a lot of spells and AA skills that I didn't have before. It also gave me several expansions that I did not have before.
I spent a lot of time organizing my spells and skills as well as my various in game menus and windows and more time figuring out what they all did.

I got used to my character again and visited old zones like Najena, Lower Guk and Sebilis just to help me remember how to fight, hunt and loot.
I've had fun exploring old places that used to be so hard (like the plane of fear) as well as old expansions that I had never used before.
I'm also having fun exploring old zones that I used to go to although some of the zones have been changed (Ocean of Tears, North and South Ro deserts and the Oasis of Marr for examples).

It's free which means that I don't have to pay for it unless I want to and there is a market place where I can buy things like mounts, illusions and various other things.

Overall, i'm having fun but who knows how long it will last but at least it's free for as long as I want it to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179441979', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1589315635}
review:
When I first played Everquest, I was a little kid, my parents and I would spend hours grinding XP from mobs much higher level than we, I have no idea how many times our party died from taking on something hard as fuck but it was probably a lot, I enjoyed playing Everquest with my family and in it's early days, it was pretty damn fun even if you spend like 2-10 hours camping near a named or something to get XP and good gear. If it weren't for Everquest's and Ultima Online's existence, the MMO/MMORPG genre would have probably died off years ago.

Most WoW clones are indirect clones of Everquest, since WoW itself is a clone of Everquest if you want to know how awesome Everquest was.

As the years went by, though, Everquest became less and less fun to play due to becoming a clone of WoW..which is kind of a paradox, I guess since WoW is a clone of Everquest, so Everquest is now an indirect clone of itself.. I mean, SOE was desperate because both EQ and EQ2 were dying because of WoW overshadowing them and so they did the only thing they thought was reasonable and so they became more like WoW... which in the long run, hurt their business greatly.. because now we got Daybreak, which is a terrible company.. Almost as bad as Nexon which is just really sad.

If Daybreak didn't own the EQ series, I would recommend EQ since it probably would have gotten better eventually if SOE was still around... Hell, Everquest Next would have came out if SOE was still around, it's really disappointing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982295752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2092, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1489687701}
review:
Everquest is a free to play MMORPG. It worked on Win 10, looked ok, played ok, sounded ok.  It is now 18 years old.   Everything about the game is so old school.  The graphics looked ok for it's age and the UI was understandable somewhat.  It has a tutorial and starter zone. 

It has 16 races and 16 classes, with both male and female gender.  Races can play certain classes.  Free to play accounts can make 2 characters.  Any SOE, Daybreak Games account will work to login.  Not sure if there are other people playing this game on the server i picked. 

Try it, if you like Retro MMORPGs.

For more info:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QJJT-PZIUwU

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2WVlK_wI4sA

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZqbstyX081A

author: {'steamid': '76561197974244121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 26874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1681995270}
review:
90% of the negative reviews listed here show the incompetence of today's gamers - or wrong expectations.

Everquest is "the" MMO game that has shaped the entire genre alongside Ultima Online. There is no other game with so much attention to detail, so much game content and so much variety.

What makes (old) Everquest different from most of today's MMOs is that you have to use your brain.
In modern times you will be shown where the quest begins and ends
(Kill 10 xy or collect 10 xy and bring them back to me) - cool thing! The maximum level is either achieved in 2 weeks via hardcore gaming or you simply use a guide 72Hours to max level!!! - Hurray!!!

-.-


Due to the many "simple" MMOs (WoW comes first) that are now available and the greater need to simply sit down in front of the PC, click wildly on the mouse and follow the instructions on the screen, the makers (not that Everquest's original development team) partially decided to jump on the big train.

A lot of things have unfortunately made some of the old Everquest flair disappear

- 1000s of players on different servers. No matter where you were, you always had enough people to chat, hang out, or just to "grind"
- Character leveling up was a lengthy process- not a primary one but a by-product of questing or further "upgrading" the character.
It was normal to take several days for a level up. With my first character I had a playtime of 124 days (124*24 hours) and reached level 57 (at that time the highest level was 60)
-Not the Leveling was in the foreground but the common questing or raiding.
-When you died, the corpse with your gear stayed where you died. If you didn't manage to get to your own corpse within a certain time, everything was gone! (everything loot all objects simple everything. ;-)
- Sometimes you walked around for hours just to explore the world or to advance a quest - or you just hang up in bazaar and played /random 100 games for the chance to win plat from other players

It was a unique experience to have been part of the development of a new genre through this game.

The biggest negative point I can think of about Everquest is the time you "have to" invest to be right in the middle of it instead of just being there.



Anyone who played Everquest in the early years knows what I'm talking about. This game doesn't deserve negative reviews about poor usability or bad graphics.

This game is a classic!!

Occasionally I look at my old server (which has already been merged with other servers several times) and I still see many old names that I know from the past :-) Unfortunately I don't have the time to play Everquest. 

Otherwise this game would be the first choice even though it has existed for almost 20 years !!

author: {'steamid': '76561197981066532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1355904000}
review:
It all began with this game. Buggy at times but that was part of its charm. Played this on Mith Marr until it merged to be AB as part of illuminati and Raging Fury. The community is what made this game along with the quirky mechanics. It was MMORPG as it should be.. no tethering of mobs, random wandering boss mobs and regular trains / wipes / corpse runs all made memorable events. The expansions continued to release challenging and interesting content, surpassing the likes of other games which tried to copy it such as WoW.. were talking top raiding guids of 60+ taking weeks to break events and complete the expansions. An overall remarkable achhievement. I left before daybreak took it over and remember how SOE ran things. 

If you want to relive it as it was some 13 years ago give project 1999 a go. The mage is a great class to start with (and you probably wont swap from them! - good ol jabober)

author: {'steamid': '76561198042775868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1488667044}
review:
The ONLY reason I even dared to download this to start with is to be able to list my old review of it here, since I actually did play this a few years ago. Heah! I don't have the foggiest idea what was worse to play back then...This or Eternal Lands...Gee, it's to bad I can't rant about Eternal Lands here on Steam! Anyway, here goes: I found this game when I was looking for game images of scarecrows online and saw a good scarecrow game image on Everquest. This in addition to the multitude of Classes and content available, which the game apparently has to offer made me want to play it. To bad it didn't turn out to be the great game I expected it to be. Here's why...

1: Download takes to long on slower computers. Period.
2: Leveling up takes way to long! Even when following an online guide I found, it was just taking to long.
3: Dying is to risky and even though you don't lose items when you die (At least I don't think), you do lose experience, so this means you have to do even more grinding. And if you have certain abilities active while running past (Would be) friendly NPC's, they WILL attack you! They'll probably kill you in one strike as well.
4: Tutorial does very little to help you. It does not teach you enough about the game (Like how to change the camera views, adjust sound and music volumes, how to quickly gain experience, etc...) and what little it does teach you does not offer you very good rewards for completing it.
5: The Kobolds at the start of the game are among the dumbest-looking monsters I think I've ever seen! Also, the monsters tend to get in your face when you're fighting them. Plus, when you're fighting them, the animations look robotic and artificial. And speaking of which...
6: The game is best played in 1st person perspective and if you don't like it, you CAN change the camera views, but all the other camera view points are even worse than the first person view point. And as for the first person view point, it looks like I'm playing as a gnome or a dwarf or some other short character race instead of a human (The race I was playing as).
7: Some of the game controls are restricted to having to press certain keys. For example, every time you want to chat, you have to click in the box before typing your message!! So damn annoying! Furthermore, you have to press a certain Enter key. Yes, it does matter which enter button you press. And my keyboard of the time was missing one of its enter buttons so I had to use a pen cap to activate the key. Also, there is no way to change this as far as I can tell! And to make this even worse, you actually have to type things out to NPC's!
8: Completing quests can be annoying cause you have to 'use' certain items on NPC's and worse yet, they do not accept stacked items, so you have to manually separate any stacked items you have before giving them to an NPC.
9: Certain items cannot be dropped or traded and must be destroyed. And in order to destroy them, you have to click on the item and 'move' it to a VERY small destroy button on your inventory window.
10: Is there pay-to-win content here? Oh, Hell yes! Just give them a certain amount of money, and you'll be rocketed all the way to Level 85! Gee, pa! They forgot to say 'halt'!

Case in point, if you're new to this game, you'll be struggling to figure out a sound strategy to make the most of it at best or throwing your keyboard across the room in frustration at worst when you realize you don't stand a chance against most of those pug-fugly Kobolds anyway. My final score...2 stars-Inferior!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055530972', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1841731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 13081, 'playtime_at_review': 104604, 'last_played': 1711245695}
review:
Firstly, I've been playing Everquest for 14 going on 15 years at this point. The amount of hours that Steam has tracked don't do me any justice. That being said, Everquest has some serious problems. There was a time when I would have recommended the game and I have recommended the game. That time is past.

Pros: 
- A good community. The community overall is full of nice and helpful people. Yes, there is some people who definitely don't fit that description but they are few and far between.

- The game being modeled after tabletop D&D. The fact that somebody can have a max level character with all the best stuff in the game and still miss/have attacks dodged by lower level mobs is hilarious. 

Cons:
- Servers. This has been a hot topic lately on both the forums and in game. The last several months especially there has been a ton of problems with servers crashing regularly and lagging. Additionally, the other major problem server related is the fact that they continue to create new servers when the game's population is relatively small. With the introduction of progression servers a lot of guilds on the regular servers have disappeared entirely which has also snowballed into people quitting the game because the rest of their friends moved on to progression servers. The developers of this game only seem to pay attention to the latest and greatest progression servers while the regular servers suffer badly. I speak from experience on this as my guild of 14 years went from about 40-50 regular raiders down to about 3 other people online every now and then besides myself. Daybreak has done an excellent job of destroying long established communities.

- Customer Service. Customer service since Daybreak took over for Sony has been hit and miss at best. Where the GM's used to help you with everything no problem now you sometimes get a GM that says "sorry, just do it again." or "sorry, just wait for a fix."

- Expansions. The expansions are a copy and paste disaster of already existing content. The last 10 expansions have been primarily copy and pasting of mobs while simply increasing the numbers (I.E. the mobs levels and how hard they hit). This sadly applies to the raid content as well as the vast majority of raid mobs have become humans or other playable races. The imagination factor of creating beastly looking creatures to slay is gone and dead.

- Lack of communication. The developers don't have a whole lot to say in regards to these issues. The only things they talk about for the most part are their "new" progression servers where you have the ability to start all over again. Additionally, when you add the game to Steam the most recent news is from back in 2013 where they announce the launch of Call of the Forsaken. They haven't had any news to add to steam in 4 years evidently. (I guess The Darkened Sea, The Broken Mirror and Empires of Kunark weren't news worthy expansions.)
***EDIT: There's no doubt that the progression servers are still very much EverQuest's "baby" but they have started posting news to Steam once again.

- Lag. If you play with any sort of graphics on the game actually runs pretty badly. I got my computer sometime around 2012-2013 and play with all the newest models and spell graphics on (as you should be able to do in any game, especially one as old as EQ). I use the Steam FPS meter to monitor how well the game performs and in group content FPS ranges anywhere from 15-60 with an average of about 25 FPS. On raids FPS will range anywhere from 0 (the meter simply disappears)-15 FPS. To put things in perspective, heres a list of my PC specs:
[list]
[*]Intel Core i7 3930k @ 3.20GHz
[*]2x NVIDIA GeForce GTX 660
[*]32 GB RAM
[/list]
*EDIT: Since I listed these PC specs I have since had one of 660's die. I upgraded to 1x NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1070 and gained virtually nothing for doing so.  I notice maybe 1 more FPS over my above mentions. (Benchmark: http://www.3dmark.com/3dm/20295692?)*
**EDIT: Recently upgraded my entire computer. i7-6950X, 2x NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti and 131 GB RAM. Nothing has changed. I've never played a game that runs so poorly. I would think given my PC's specs it would run so good I'd have to turn on V-sync but that's not even close to the case. (Benchmark: http://www.3dmark.com/3dm/20373384?)**

- Graphics. The game still very much looks like an old Playstation 1/Playstation 2 game. The graphics were good for back when this game was created. Some of the graphics were even upgraded to look better in 2001. However, there hasn't been any modernization improvements since then. Games today like RIFT and Elder Scrolls Online are significantly more pleasant to look at. Additionally, when you first enter a zone the game has a tendency to zone you in before any of the textures load. That being said the entire game world ends up looking like gray squares/rectangles and nude character models until the textures catch up.

review: This game was good 10 years ago.Now it is junk, crashes, log-in issues, lag, and 15 year old graphics are what its about now. EQ is free to play but with conditions added. Daybreak makes new expansions with consist of 75% old zones that have been upgraded to a higher level and maybe 1 or 2 new ones. Mobs are copy and paste from all other zones so no new ones in a long time.All the special events are old ones that just keep coming back. Once in awhile something interesting will come along but far and few between. So after reading this i cant say any thing good about EQ anymore, theres other free to play games that are a lot better. But the one upside to EQ  is that it does have a nice community, people are always willing to offer advice that will help you along.

review:
dont let the low hours fool you. i played this waaaaaaaay longer than steam has been around and was how i bonded with my father. This is the OG MMORPG untill absolute simplicity ruined the mmorpg genre. My only grip as to the merc disbabnds all player interactons and i can pretty much solo this game almost leaving the classes as just a husk of their former selves when you needed to play with others and make friends. 

i hate my generation for ruining the social aspects of mmorpg's. 9/10 still the greatest mmorpg on the market without the cartoon "toons" and retardedly simplistic combat and classes because even though you can almost solo with every class the classes are still able to do their job very well when in a group and you can wipe areas with good players. 

players arent your cringy new player who trolls the hell out of you because youre new, i havent played this game in like 13 years and im 20 almost 21 and they stilled aided me with my forgotten knowledge of the game. 

10/10. player base is not cancer/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197962171909', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 25098, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4656, 'last_played': 1502220279}
review:
Don't get me wrong - I love everquest.  I put a good 5 years into this game when it first came out and have not been able to find an MMO that gave me the same feeling accomplisment that Everquest gave me when I would grind for months for one damn item.  

I thought I would go back and see what has happened to the game since 2004 - and I was having a great time playing it too.  It's a little more user friendly now-a-days and it copied a bunch from multiple MMO's in terms of the UI and quests that are available.  It even updated its graphics a bit.  

My problem came when I tried to buy a months membership to  Daybreak games through what they call Kronos.  This is when things went downhill.  I thought I would support the game and get some of the benefits of being a member - a win win.  This is when I got banned.  They gave me zero notification about the ban, not even an email.  Through their page I was told I needed to make a new account to put in a ticket and contest the ban.  I did that close to a week ago and still have yet to hear back from their support team. I even entered an second ticket and sent multiple emails.  It's a bit ridiculous.  Apparetly if you fat finger some numbers on a credit card account, it doesn't deny the charge like any other game or website  (again I just assume this is what happened to me)- it just bans you outright and give you no rhyme or reason.  

So, sadly I would never recommend this game to anyone just based on Daybreak having horrible customer support.  Go play Rift - any time I would put in a ticket Trion would respond quickly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086169552', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 24581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2679, 'last_played': 1639140545}
review:
I love this game - and I have since the day it came out. If you play this game expecting it to be somethning else, you are going to be disappointed. EQ is a unique game. It is not Wow or a Final Fantasy game or Guild Wars or ESO or anything else. It is EQ. That may sound obvious to some, but it is the main point I need to make to my gamer friends. They instantly hate it because the "problems" have been fixed in other games. Maybe they are not problems...

It is worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992747360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 20022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16881, 'last_played': 1697984997}
review:
Un Mmorpg que después de 14 años sigue funcionando es por algo. Es un buen juego que sigue manteniendo su esencia original ya que necesitas un grupo para poder avanzar. No es un juego ni fácil ni rápido no subirás al nivel máximo en 24h de juego. Los mmorpg en los últimos años cambiaron a juegos fáciles que en poco tiempo alcanzas el nivel máximo y Everquest siempre fue un mmorpg que necesita dedicación y paciencia, es el juego en el que blizzard se fijo(copio dicen otros) para crear su mmorpg. El motor gráfico como es lógico no es ni actual, ni impresionante, es antiguo.
En resumen si tienes paciencia, te gusta la dificultad y los retos este mmorpg te gustará. Si tienes prisa por subir de nivel y por matar sin peligro ni dificultad tienes todos los demás mmorpg, Everquest es de los pocos mmorpg con dificultad que quedan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073096968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 23681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18838, 'last_played': 1518643727}
review:
[b]Dear Reader,[/b]

You will probably disagree with this review due to the age of the game, unless you are an odd person (like myself) or have been playing Everquest since its early days (like myself).  If you disagree with what is said below, I am not sorry, you were not forced to read it.  *trollface*

~~~~~,~`~~,'{@

[h1]Semi-official, possibly tangential, review; by an unimportant clod you don't care about:[/h1]
[b]Audio:[/b] 4/10
Alright, some of Everquest's music is so much a part of my earlier years that I smile when I hear it.  Then I remember why I turned off loading screen music after the fourth or fifth time loading, and fix the discrepancy.  Nostalgiac, yet annoying.

At some point in the past few years the developers added a lot of new audio files for combat, some zones, and the character select screen.  Some of them are great, some are just ok, most are nothing to write home to mom about.

Banshees and skeletons are annoying.  Like, [i]valley girl movie[/i] annoying, oh my god.

Most people play on Mute or with other noise in the background (movies/tv, music, voice chat, etc.)  The exception is during raid events, where some of the more serious players will set audio triggers to fire whenever an event emote is set off.

[b]Graphics:[/b] Originally, 2/10 - Currently, 5/10
These are definitely one of the biggest complaints people have, but if you'd played in the original days you would have a much higher opinion of the graphics they've been able to squeeze out of this archaic engine.  Spend a few days translating the instructions for "Project 1999" and get on a classic server, playing with original graphics, and you'll pop some confetti when you come back to modern EQ.  Katta Castrum: Deluge does not shake occasionally as part of lore, ignore that event text.  It shakes at the memory of how crap the entire game used to look.

If you refuse to play the game based on its looks alone you'll never find the actual value of the game buried under months of personal experience and character growth.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] 8/10
This is where the game shines, in spite of its age.  There are a few glaring issues for me, which is why it falls to 8/10, but those could be fixed in a rebuild of the game.  The (complex) potential of most characters in this game takes a long time or a great teacher to figure out.  If someone takes the approach of dressing in the best gear and reading a build guide they can survive, but will never thrive and amaze their fellow players.  Experimentation and challenge lead to discovery, and to game-breaking designs. [spoiler]*cough* nerf bat! *cough*[/spoiler]

Pros -[list]
[*]Characters of the same class can feel pretty different depending on how each player builds their clickies, AA choices, spells prepared, etc.
[*]Most classes are not shoehorned into a specific role, because there are so many alternatives available.  There is no "this is the caster DPS class, that is the melee DPS class, you can't tank unless you play one of these" situations.  The game has multiple DPS options, multiple healer options, multiple tank options, and most of them can change roles on the fly.
[*]Alternate Advancement points don't just make your character tougher, they can completely change the way you play the game.  The rate and frequency of their gain can also change the power of your character at any given level.  If you go for max levels and then start gaining AA you will be made of paper, but if you max out your AA every 1-5 levels you can be easily 4-5x tougher than an equally-leveled character of your class.[/list]

Cons -[list]
[*]Slay Undead. [spoiler]wait... what?[/spoiler]  That's right, the ability that most clearly defines a Paladin in the upper levels.  "But your second biggest toon is a Paladin!"  And?  The problem is not the ability, it's the implementation and ensuing problems it has created.   Here's how it works...

There are two "Knights" in EQ.  Shadowknights and Paladins.  They share most weapons and have roughly equivalent armor and AA/Spell lines.  The problem is that Slay Undead is tied to the base damage of a weapon instead of a subtype of damage like a Rogue's Backstab skill.  This means that when a Paladin or Shadowknight wields a weapon, we'll say base damage of 100, the Paladin can strike undead for massive amounts compared to the shadowknight.  This means undead need more HP than most mobs, and need to hit harder to be a threat to Paladins.  However, in order for a Shadowknight to then stand a chance against an undead mob, they need a weapon that does enough damage to not spend 10 minutes trying to beat it down.  But when they get more damage...  so does the Paladin...

Slay Undead should have been a subtype of damage like Backstab damage, with its own display on the weapon.  This would have helped avoid Con #2...

[*]Power Creep - Because each expansion the undead need to be stronger to survive the Paladin, everything else needs to be empowered so other classes can survive against them.  Spells do more damage, armor has higher stats, other weapons do more damage.

Because other classes are boosted to take on undead, the living mobs need to be strengthened in order to be a viable threat to the other classes.  Next expansion the undead ramp up more, so other classes need a bigger boost to survive them, which gives a bigger boost to Slay Undead, so the next expansion makes them even stronger. It's a cycle that saw strikes of 15-20k Slay Undead damage ramping up into the hundreds of thousands after a handful of expansions.  "Current Content" trash mobs that were hitting for 400 damage were boosted to 4500 damage after a few expansions, and now strike for 20,000 damage in the modern game.[/list]


[h1]Subjective Opinion:[/h1]
Everquest is a game unlike any other that I have played.  I've tried WoW and almost all of its clones.  I have played multiplayer Minecraft, persistent worlds in Neverwinter Nights, Path of Exile, Dungeons & Dragons: Eberron Unleashed, and a cartload of other multiplayer or MMO games, and nothing keeps my interest or brings me back once I've left, the way Everquest does.

Yes, it is 'ugly' compared to new games, but it runs on a game engine built in the early-mid 90's.  Yes, at 17 years old the developers have other games they are putting more effort into, can you blame them?  The code for the base game is so outdated that it's hard to keep adding content without causing one problem or another.  Yes, the playerbase has diminished due to graphics, cost of expansions, and the interactions with many of the more vocal players.

Most of the people I enjoy the game with are not vocal in general chat channels due to the outspoken negative personalities that dominate them.  I appreciate the quiet players that have bothered to learn their class, or are trying a new class and actively seeking feedback on how to play it better.  It can take weeks, sometimes months, to find a really solid group that you truly enjoy spending time with.  Most modern players lack the patience or social graces to "put up with" that time investment, because other MMO's are designed to reward them immediately.  Designed to keep pushing them to new things, new things, higher numbers, more new things, and they don't have to actually grind for their objectives.

I see some people complain about the content difference between current expansions and old expansions, but you do have to realize that the developers don't have to spend any time on this old game and people will still play it.  This isn't their flagship game and will not receive the majority of their attention, so the level of time and detail they do invest in keeping it running is amazing to me.  I do believe they could salvage it completely if they rebuilt Everquest with a few design tweaks in a modern engine, but kept the atmosphere and content mostly identical.  [spoiler]*sigh* wouldn't that be lo...  made you look.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970544298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 32347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30074, 'last_played': 1525482246}
review: A classic MMORPG that's still worth playing today.

author: {'steamid': '76561198242885120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 26295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1686463180}
review:
Oh Everquest, I loved you so much! This game was absolutely amazing when it first launched and for the first four or five expansions. The current state of the game does leave much to be desired. The core gameplay has changed a bit and I feel there is not much of a challenge to the game any longer. I was a bit shocked to see how much the player base had dwindled and how many bots roam the landscapes of Norrath these days.

The game has turned in to a cash shop nightmare and has really taken the core elements away from the original spirit of Everquest. Some folks might find an enjoyable game, but with the addition of mercs, this really takes away from the entire point of making new friends to tackle content. I suppose some guilds might be active and still keep that spirit alive, but overall, this game has taken a huge plunge from the amazing game it once was.

It feels like you're playing a shadow of the original game these days. I was very disappointed with my return to the game and seeing everything that has changed. The time lock servers were fun for a little while and helped to capture some of the old school nostalgic moment, but the live version is out of control. I regret to say that Everquest might be appealing to some, but the dive in the player base speaks for what is has become.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009840027', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 251002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68218, 'last_played': 1695685669}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972461711', 'num_games_owned': 863, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 42159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27069, 'last_played': 1708723990}
review:
Have played Everquest since Beta testing it 17 years ago and I still come back to every once in a while.  It's worth playing for anyone who is an MMORPG fan, if only just to see where the modern formula truly started.  It probably takes a bit of adjusting for modern MMO players, though you might be surprised how much you enjoy it.  There simply is 17 years of content that you can experience at your own pace.  Open world free-roaming games are becoming popular now and Everquest will appeal to those players somewhat.

WoW and EQ2 (launched the same month) both started the quest grinding pattern in MMOs (one of the few deviations from the EQ formula).  EQ has the original kill grind method.  In a lot of ways I like the kill grinding pattern better, until Old Republic quest grinding was novel for the first handful of hours but it becomes just as tedious as kill grinding.  Kill grinding on the other hand is much more straightforward... you kill things and you get exp.  This frees up quests to be more meaningful than level grinding, they are actually lore centered and/or item/reward centered for the most part (minus daily tasks etc).

This is where it all really started, it's worth playing just to experience a bit of MMORPG history... well and you might find a couple decades later it was worth it too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070314458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 23535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21786, 'last_played': 1691782363}
review:
Simply worth trying out, if you are playing absolutely alone seek a guild for help throughout your experience of the game. If guilds aren't your style you can "box" which is where you play multiple characters at once. Which may seem boring but actually in my opinion adds a lot of depth/decision making depending on the characters you play. The game is old, very old, but any information you seek on it is available. A huge problem I notice when I play with new players is they do not have the maps downloaded, if you do not have the maps downloaded getting around the world can be a struggle. Some may welcome the challenge of having no map. I would advise any new players to pick a class with access to pets/summons. These classes generally fair well on their own early on and later into the game, this allows you to learn the mechanics of the game. Everquest used to be fairly punishing if you died in game you had to do a corpse run to retrieve all of your hard earned gear, nowadays its just a loss of experience unless you make the corpse run or pay a npc to summon it for you. Once you hit about level 50 (max lvl is 110 w/ expansion) in game which should take you a few days you will need to decide if you want to pay the subscription fee to gain access to features such as "AA" alternate abilitys, some of these are passive increases and others are active skills. Sadly you need access to these for much later gameplay to be effective in level appropriate content. 
Overall I would give the game a try
If you really like its core mechanics and have kept in mind it is one of the oldest games and ofcourse one of the oldest mmo's and you have read this far and still do not like the concept of paying a sub fee to enjoy the full game.
I would advise you to look into Pantheon Rise of the Fallen a new MMO with old concepts
Side note, I have much more time than listed dumped into this game :P

review: Having played this game for 16 years and some it has very interesting cooperative game play. There's insane amount of content to explore, you can play in groups with your friends and join a raiding guild for challenging 50+ player events. Graphics may not be top notch, but the game play offers a lot more depth and that entirely makes up for it.  It's a game that has so many goals to achieve that it is nearly impossible to finish. There are no quick wins here and eventually game will require cooperative play with other people.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972595109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1458681679}
review:
EverQuest --was-- the best MMO that I ever experienced. What people should understand is that EverQuest of old does not exist. There are emulated servers like P1999 that try to recreate the original EQ experience - that alone should tell you how much the current EQ has changed from its inception.

Today, the problems of top-heavy population are very real, and catastrophic for enjoyment of the game. 99% of zones and content are ghost towns, completely unused. 99% of quests and items are obsolete. The game now gives you equipment in "starter packs" that is better than anything you can quest for or loot in the early game. A bad solution to a real problem (no new players), which renders all content except the last couple expansions worthless. 1-75 content is just there to grind levels these days. Maybe even 1-90. If you need gear better than the game just gives you, you won't want to hunt for it. Instead, you'll want to hit the Auction House, which is full to bursting of better gear than you could ever loot for dirt cheap prices.

Agreed that this is not an MMO for new players. Frankly it's not even an MMO for many of us vets, who were around at the beginning. There are still some people playing - three or four chars at a time - but what keeps them going is often the amount they've already invested in the game. Splitting from characters you've invested literally years of your life into is not easy. But few will straight-up tell you that they enjoy the game as much as they ever did.

By all means, give it a try. It's free after all. But don't expect the legendary MMO you might have heard people talk about. That game no longer exists.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039388326', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4765, 'last_played': 1676310425}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019338462', 'num_games_owned': 2795, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 15865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15737, 'last_played': 1480575954}
review:
Thinking about playing EverQuest for the first time? Don't. Only come back if you've played back in the day and you are returning for a nostalgia run. This is not an MMO you should visit if you've never played before. Why? Well, let's see:

[b]Terrible Developer Communication[/b]
-- The developers have poor communication with the community. They never explain what is happening when the servers are down, they never explain why they decided to take X path instead of Y path, they lock any threads on the official forums if you criticize them, and they don't reply to any threads outside of their own. Unacceptable and completely unprofessional.

[b]Outdated[/b]
-- If you've played back in the day then you'll be used to the graphics, thus you probably won't be too taken aback by how ugly EverQuest looks.

-- You also have the jumbled, unorganized, messy UI the game gives you. When you first log onto your character you'll be surprised how I wasn't exaggerating. It's that bad. I honestly think it's the worst UI out there from any other game I have ever played.

[b]Lazy Developers & Lack of Content[/b]
Another developer complaint? Yes! They deserve it. They are in charge of what direction the game is going, and they are always going down the wrong path. Incompetent?

-- Back when the first EverQuest expansion was released ('Kunark') you got 28 zones, that's right [b]28[/b] zones to explore and tackle. How many zones in the current expansion of EverQuest? In 'Empires of Kunark' you get.... [b]7[/b] zones! Hahaha... It's hard not to laugh when you compare the two. This expansion takes place on the same continent of Kunark. You lack 21 zones to explore due to the current lazy developer team. It's quite sad.

-- No maps. That's right, you get very little in-game maps. You need to go to a third-party website to download maps. This shouldn't happen...

-- Speaking of the current expansion, did you know they have the nerve to charge the same amount they charged for 'Kunark' for the most recent expansion 'Empires of Kunark'? With 1/4 the content! How people accept this is beyond me. Actually, thinking about it, they are probably lifelong players who can't take off their nostalgia goggles to see things clearly.

[b]Lack of Players / Forced to 'Box' to Make Progress[/b]
-- Let me explain how things are going to go for you if you are new and/or if you decide to come back:

[b]Level 1[/b]: "Wow... this is an ugly UI. Um... What do I do?"
[b]2 - 11[/b]: "Ok, I survived the tutorial. I was alone the entire time... Maybe I can join a group once I leave here?"
[b]12 - 50[/b]: "Crescent Reach looks cool! Nice zone.", "Hmm... still no groups even though I'm level 50! What the hell? Where is everybody?", "How did that guy writing that review on Steam know this would happen? Does this happen to everybody?"
[b]51 - 65[/b]: "What the hell happened? Why is it so hard to level up? I'm getting less than 1% a kill and it's taking FOREVER to make progress.", "Also, where are the groups? This game is top-heavy, I guess. Maybe if I keep pushing forward I can finally get a group."
[b]66 - 75[/b]: "Ok, I'm going to quit. The grind is real and it's a real bore. Not even difficult, just killing hundred of enemies for less than 1% EXP."
[b]75 - 105[/b]: "Finally, I'm high enough level to group with somebody!"

You: Hi, level XX [class here], want to group?
Players: No, you're not in our clique, so...
You: ...Damn it! Guess I'll "box"

[b]What is 'Boxing'?[/b] - Boxing is a term used when a player has more than one account -- usually one or two additional accounts. You do this so you can tackle the games content since the game was designed for you to have a group. If you control three accounts, you can place three mercenaries (computer controlled players) in your party to complete your party. Instead of playing $15 a month, you pay $45 (if you have three accounts total). Depending on how good you are at controlling all your characters you can tackle every single thing in EverQuest besides most raids. Solo content? Obviously. Group content? Depends on what classes you picked and how good you are. Raids? A lot of old raids you can take, however once you reach the 12th (out of 23) or so expansion it nearly becomes impossible due to mechanics and needing 6+ players to enter the zone.

[b]In conclusion...[/b]
Only come back if you have played before and you want to take care of that itch you have. Don't bother with EverQuest if you are new and want to try an "old school" MMO. It's not worth it. Any other MMO besides EverQuest, is what I suggest. The game shows no signs of improving, terrible developers, not enough content, and most importantly: no players!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198152637382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 32199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13843, 'last_played': 1589832386}
review:
I needed something to do while I download this game for 800th time, so I figured, why not post a review.  A review?  Well, not really.  More a long the lines of... well, just read it.

You see, EverQuest is the kind of game you can lose your life to and not care one bit.  I know, because I was practically raised in this world.  I started back in 1999, when I was 6 years old.  Watching my Father play, I was captivated the moment I saw it - When I wasn't play it on the computer, I was LARPing it with my Brothers.

I maintain to this day, that I was not raised in Unnamed City, Canada, North America, World.  No, I was Born in Kelethin, Greater Faydark, Faydwer, Norrath.  I was raised and molded by this world, the experiences I had and the people I met.

I haven't, REALLY played in some years, but I still have solid friendships, to this day, that were forged in the Norrathian environment.  I still pop on every now and again, just to catch up.

Every time I do, it's like visiting an old friend.  You haven't seen eachother for a while.  You catch up.  Talk about what is new, get lost n your friendship and despite that you have both done some growing, it's like your friendsip has never changed.

I still get giddy with I hear the loading music.

This game is more than just a game.  It truely is a world in which you may lose yourself in.

It may be dated and have a lot of content that serves no purpose, but, it is there.  Just waiting to be explored.

If you don't mind soloing or have a few like-minded friends - Play this game.

Do not play it for the race.  Do not race yourself through all 115 Level (Maybe there are more now.  There were only 70 when I left)

Do not play it like most enter MMOs, a mad race to get to the top of the world, ASAP.

The expression, "Stop and smell the roses" could not be more true, than in this game.  You will not regret it.  Explore this world.  Breath in it's lore.  Become an inhabitant of Norrath, not sure a player vieing for the best gear.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986712903', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1478819015}
review: Unless you have an emotional connection to this game, I can't imagine you having a fun time playing it. Everything about the game is significantly outdated and unoptimized, to the point where even doing the simplest tasks can be a huge pain in the rear. Obviously this game has its niche audience that loves it - and they certainly have their own good reasons! - but if you're not part of this niche audience, I highly recommend finding another game - really, *any* other game - to satisfy your fantasy RPG kick. This game is as traditional as traditional gets, man, and sometimes tradition is best left in the past.

author: {'steamid': '76561198331276844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 273009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12198, 'last_played': 1678457597}
review: Had to pick this game up for mainly nostolgic reasons , and i am glad i did . This throw back is as good to play now as it was back in 1999!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032115570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 66715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19414, 'last_played': 1604885474}
review:
A friend of mine spent many years playing this game back when it was popular. I have given it a try and for an older game I find it is enjoyable.  I have played many MMORPGS and with all of the pretty graphics, I find they all lack something this game has. I keep going back to this and both loving and hating my friend for introducing me to the Everquest games a few years ago.

  It has dated graphics and I am not sure about the population but for an older game it has a lot of servers. This game is fun and worth trying. I enjoyed it and still play it. As I said it has what most newer games are missing. I would love to see this one updated with some newer graphics as well as a few other things. It has what the more modern games lack. Challenge, huge world,  and very fun classes. It is not for the type who want things handed to them and need their hand held the entire way through though. Like so many others.  Fine alone, better with friends. Not a bad way to waste time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960789593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 134831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86377, 'last_played': 1698985734}
review: This is my favorite game of all time. I have played for over a decade and still have more love for this game than any other MMORPG I have ever played. It isn't the easiest for beginners to get used too, but once you get the hang of it you will find out very soon if it is or isnt for you. The majority of people that play this game are like me. They played back in the early 2000s and have played other MMOs in the meantime, but find themselves still drawn to EQ. This game excels at facilitating the necessity of community required within the game. With the new Time-Locked Progression(TLP) servers, the game does a good job of making it an improved version of the older expansions. I have played many MMOs and this one is endgame-heavy just like a lot of today's MMORPGs, but the grind is still fun and exploring Norrath will never get old. As a long time MMORPG player, it's baffling how this 20 year old game is still so engaging for me. I highly recommend it for people who like MMORPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156142963', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 985, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 985, 'last_played': 1451873071}

review: I used to play this back when it first came out, and every other year or so, I gotta go back and see how it's evolved.  :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197970640805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 17837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16461, 'last_played': 1570368174}
review:
Played since 1999. A pretty good game, but REALLY clunky in comparison to modern MMO. On the other hand, there's more content than you can probably ever play and, sadly, more than you'd probably want to. Certain parts of the game world haven't been updated since 1999, and the rusty swords and rawhide-leather armour you'd pick up there at lvl 8 could never compare to the magic, stat boosting, enchanted gear that you get just by ambling through the tutorial. This just means that you'll miss-out on most of the game zones, simply because you'll never have a reason to visit them. You'll also find (or, more likely, completely fail to notice) entire expansion-worths of mechanics that you'll never use, like the 'Lost Dungeons of Noreath'.

-HOWEVER-

If you can find a guild of likeminded individuals, you'll probably have a blast. It's a huge world with tons to see... even if you can never be arsed to visit the Kunark or Velious landmasses. I'm not sure if they have any 'vintage' servers. If they get some, I'll be back in a flash.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966796029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 14097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12966, 'last_played': 1468036074}
review: Everquest is great if you're looking for a nostalgia trip back to 1999 era MMOs, but otherwise is lacking in many departments. I wouldn't recommend this to any new players, but if an EQ veteran wants to scratch that nostalgia itch the Time Locked Progression servers can be very fun for a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263675843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1401, 'last_played': 1475207558}
review:
EverQuest is basically the only game you'll ever need.
Incredible world filled with so much content. Group interactions basically a necessity. Great player base (many aged 30+ who grew up playing the game and came back for more)

For new players: The low levels can be a bit rough, but as you level up you'll start to realize how much this game has to offer. I recommend the progression servers to get the same feeling we all did back in the days (ahh.. sweet Velious days)

The only problem with this game is if that you're single, you'll probably stay that way. If you're already happily married and playing this game: consider yourself one of the lucky ones! If your significant other plays also: you should go buy a lottery ticket.

The nostalgia us ol' EQ Veterans get with this game is like a recovered drug addict that is about to relapse.

Note: The soundtrack is pretty awful, but the nostalgia of it somehow brings tears to your eyes like the best love song you've ever heard.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981573997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 4766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1746, 'last_played': 1475474568}
review: Where to begin? IDK! Memories - I used to play when there was a total of 7 expsansion! on A.O.L LOL when my parents got a phone call it would boot me off the server, take me 5 mins to reconnect, due to 56k dial up internet!! The struggles of running around for hundreds of hours doing what you may ask, well chillin in the BAZAAR getting drunk, farming spiderling silks to sell, killing millions of bad guys, and completely forgetting about reality around me! This game is great and will always be IMO. I love the Opening music THEME, the music in this game gives me goosebumps hearing them all over again 10 years later! I played 2 accounts at one time when there was a 14.99 subscription fee, WORTH!! ALL in all this game has changed and there are new things, thats life! People still play this game, amazing! Thanks Bryan for getting me addicted to EQ like 17 years ago! good times my man!! good times!

author: {'steamid': '76561198081407066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 33419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 133, 'playtime_at_review': 4026, 'last_played': 1710710546}
review:
Amazing game even by modern standards.

I never ever played this game before 2016, and trust me: this is propably the best MMORPG that I ever played.
First for all, its: free, HUGE, compex, hard, "mature" (NO ANIME, NO SEXUALIZATION, no asian girls with oversized swords, pandas and other stuff) and VERY, VERY playable.

I did try dozen of MMORPGS in past decade, and except maybe Star Trek Online I never got that hooked...
Graphics might be not the best, but it does have good "retro" felling. Also when it comes to architecture or clothing - developers did awesome job.

Seriously: if you ever moaned about silly mmorpgs, you might love this game.
Exploration alone is good reason to play it.


Negative points:

- Interface is dated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042204542', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1473038691}
review:
[h1]What is Everquest?[/h1]

Everquest is kind of like being thrusted straight back into the 90s, when your computer could barely run solitare and your mother was pretty hot. I had never played Everquest back in it's hay day, I instead played World of Warcraft back in the Cataclysm days, but it was obvious that when I first started up EQ, that it was the OG of MMORPGS. 

[h1]Enough chit chat, what's it like in-game?[/h1]

It's very complicated in my opinion. But obviously people opt for a different experience over the 'hand-holding' that most MMOs give you nowadays. You kind of feel a sense of 'freedom' when you embrace these mechanics in particular.

Combat is pretty niche, similar to the likes of Morrowind. Honestly, I could only relate to Morrowind as that was the only game that I played that had similar combat mechanics. 

Interacting with NPCs was quite profound too. You would have to either press the 'h' key on your keyboard or say 'hail' (hitler) to the NPC you wanted to talk to. From there you have to continue the conversation through the chat box with the highlighted words.

[h1]Is it fair on the average 'newbie'?[/h1]

HAHAHAHA no. Simply put, this game is pretty rock hard honestly. I found myself dying in pretty awkward situations and failed to see why the game hated me so much. It obviously takes a lot of time to master what's in game for sure.

[h1]Conclusion?[/h1]

I honestly don't know what to say about this game. If you want to feel the rush of nostalgia and cheesy 90s movies and commercials throbbing through your veins, then give it a shot. If you're looking for an MMO to try however and haven't really scratched the surface with online gaming, this game might not be for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122946837', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1621302169}
review:
I was actually playing EverQuest off and on for quite a while since I was 12 years old (so, about 14 years now) -- introduced to it by my parents. I remember back in the day, when it took FOREVER for me to get level 8, and I thought I was so awesome when I finally got level 13, even though my parents were WAY higher level. I couldn't even comprehend getting that high at the time.

There are a lot of ads now in the game, as is expected of pretty much all Free To Play games. They want to hook you in to those micro-transactions. Admittedly, I have purchased a few aesthetic items off of the store. The game, even in it's current free-to-play format, still brings back memories during times of when it was subscription based.

All in all, if you used to like EverQuest back in the day, and don't mind the free-to-play model, then this game is fantastic. If you're looking for something new, then this isn't it. This game is quite old, so nothing really new here. If you liked the combat and gameplay system before, the basics of it haven't really changed.

Personally, I like having to collect bones for my summons, and meditating, or resting, versus how most modern MMOs take such things into account. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198209473709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1472283482}
review:
에퀘 덕분에 온라인 게임 시 갖춰야 할 기본 예법들(간단한 인사나 상호 존중, 존대같은 인간이라면 기본적으로 해야할 것들 말고) 예를 들면 다들 전투 중인데 혼자 룻한다거나 동의 없이 혼자 템 꿀걱하는 닌자짓을 한다거나 타인 장비 볼 때 동의를 구하는 등...(에퀘는 모든 게 소규모 파티와 길드에 의존한 레이드 시스템이라 노매너는 상상조차 못했다.) 기존에 했던 국산 온라인겜에선 알 수 없었던 그런 것들을 알 수 있었다.

그리고 게임 자체도 탱커 딜러 힐러 누커 매져등 각자 역할이 있어서 자신이 이를 철저하게 이른바 '밥값'을 해야 파티도 제대로 굴러갔다. 이 또한 기존의 온라인 게임에선 이런 점이 없거나 있더라도 희박했다. 이는 후에 대성공을 거둔 wow를 시작할 때도 게임을 쉽게 익히게 해줬다.(지금 와우는 템만 좋으면 인던따위 혼자 무쌍으로 털지만 오리지널때는 아니었다.)

나에게 미친 에퀘의 모든 것을 기리기 위해 난 어느 게임을 하든 '안토니카' 라는 아이디를 쓰며 에퀘를 잊지 않았다. 하지만 추억에 잠겨서 이 게임을 다시 손댄건 실수였다. 그냥 고인을 기리며 아름다운 추억을 기억하며 명복을 바라야 했는데 내가 그만 극악무도한 짓을 하고 말았다. 고인이 그립다고 관을 꺼내서 시신을 꺼낸 것이나 다름 없는 행동이었기 때문이다. 아마 오르페우스가 저승의 마지막 문턱에서 뒤돌아 아내를 보았을 때 아내의 모습이 그러했을 것이다. 한국섭이 닫힌 뒤 에퀘를 뒤로한 채 너무 편하고 아름다운 것들만 봐서 그랬을런지도 모르겠다...

그래도 옛정이 남아 차마 비추천은 하지 못하겠다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089334302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5310, 'last_played': 1661380603}
review:
For all the 12 year olds looking for a new game, just walk away and take your bad reviews with you. This game takes time and isn't as action packed as all the newer games coming out, so don't expect much from a game that has been out for as many years as this one. It is confusing when you just start playing, but it is a massive game with 16 classes to choose from, and so many zones that I doubt you will ever see them all. I was introduced to this game by my dad and played with my brother and him, so I guess I'm a little biased but it's still annoying af to see people going in thinking it's gonna be a new MMO. (Yes, it does advertise premium but you can exit out of the small pop-up with a click, and as for the premium, you literally don't need it for anything if you just want to play the game)
Also, I have a LOT more hours than this outside of steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043604765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1466742843}

author: {'steamid': '76561197965771435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1128, 'last_played': 1687965532}
review:
es una obra maestra con mas de 15 años a sus espaldas, uno de los mmorpgs supervivientes del antiguo triunvirato (EQ, lineage ,Dark age of camelot) y sus veintipico expansiones lo confirman. los graficos siguen siendo de hace 10 años, pero su comunidad siempre ha preferido mantenerlos y que esta inmensidad de juego se pueda jugar en casi cualquier pc y que esos recursos se usen en ampliar el inmenso mundo de norrath y sus planos.
cada expansion es tan grande como el WoW y los cientos de lugares ya olvidados por muchos jugadores son una fascinante aventura de redescubrimiento.

La vieja escuela aun seguimos al pie del cañon, y el everquest sigue paso a paso con su gran historia
