review: Play the game that was among those that spawned the massive online game genre.  Both free to pay and paid options exist.  Graphics are as simple as you'd expect a game that began in 1999.  Regular updates and expansions are pushed out.  Nostalgia is still there, as are your old characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970611285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1612921679}
review:
Best MMORPG of all time, but if you haven't played it by now it is likely too late as the game might be hard to get into since it is so old now and has low population and old control mechanics that are hard to adapt to. 

They just don't make MMOs like this anymore. MMOs where the game was about exploring new locations, the lore, and slow steady progression. MMOs today are just hubs littered with thousands of mind numbing quests to level 1-Max in a month, grouping not required. MMOs today are about getting to end game and raiding endlessly. EQ had its fair share of raiding, but when I think of EverQuest that is not the part that I think of. My initial character that took a long time to level up (probably a year to get max level) and slowly progressed from zone to zone and the different people I met along the way that I grouped with is what I remember most. No other MMO has had a similar experience since because they just go by too fast and too easy to get people to the end game, and with instance queues (usually multi-server) there just isn't any sense of server community in current MMOs.

At the end game EQ was similar to what we know today in MMOs, nothing that special, with the primary difference being competition over spawns since there were no instances. This was fun and not fun at the same time. It formed different guild rivalries if we stole a spawn or they did, but sometimes you would have to change plans due to not being at the right place at the right time. The more proactive your guild was in monitoring spawns and mobilizing quickly and efficiently the greater chance that your guild would be the strongest on the server. It was a different mechanic than current MMO raids, but ultimately that isn't where EverQuest shined to me.

The EQ lore is what kept me playing. The locations and the story lines were there, but you had to find them, they weren't laid out for you with giant exclamation points. EQ has some of the best zones in any MMO I've played and I would recommend playing it today just to get a chance to experience certain zones and dungeons, but again this game will be hard to pick up at this point with its age.

There are still people that play the game, but they're all at end game raiding. I would recommend this game still today as a single player experience to just experience some of the zones and game lore, but it would be hard to recommend it to play end game with all the catching up that would be required.

A new EverQuest comes out in 2015 (probably) called EverQuest Next so be on the lookout for that one, it looks to be doing some really great things in the MMORPG genre..

author: {'steamid': '76561197990705973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 6391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2404, 'last_played': 1426045277}
review:
Play the game that started it all! The graphics may be old, but the game is still as fun as ever. 

The F2P model transition has been handled well, the limitations are resonable and non-restrictive (the biggest one is the limit of 2 chars per server, which makes sense to stop multibox bot trains), and players can't buy power, just a lot of cosmetic and convenience items. I've enjoyed looking like a Froglock Phantom since I came back.

It's EQ, in it's best form, and if you didn't play back in the day, don't let the graphics turn you away. Norrath is massive. No other MMO has even come close to hitting the scope and scale of an online world as this game did 15 years ago. And, in those 15 years, Norrath's gotten a lot bigger. A lot.

Bottom line: I haven't had this much fun in an MMO since Bill Clinton was President.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070492617', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1542, 'last_played': 1450987469}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030607472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 40273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37425, 'last_played': 1658398033}
review:
EverQuest is a very old game. Well, sort of. It predates most of the MMO market by a few years, especially a certain other exceptionally popular game anyone remotely familiar with the genre will instantly know. In its heyday, it was one of the most popular MMOs, with about 100,000 subscribers, give or take. The epic scale of the raids still hasn't been replicated to this day.
But has it aged well? Sure.
EverQuest has always been about change. Sure, you can't have a dynamic influence on the world in most cases, but the game has always been changing. Where once you couldn't do anything without a group unless you were a specific class, now nearly everyone is capable of soloing for experience.
Don't get me wrong, the game is still old and looks old, but there's a wonderful charm to it that other games really haven't come close to replicating.
Oh, and it's HUGE. In the old days, it used to be said that it took six hours to run from one end of the map to the other on foot. Well, the game has gotten bigger since then, to the point that they've added a number of hub zones to make travel easier. The down side to this truly epic size is that very few zones are consistently occupied by players.
There's also a bit of a disjointed aesthetic to the game. While many older zones and models have been updated over time, just as many have not. While Freeport and the surrounding Commonlands have received overhauls to the point it's almost a joke in the community, Qeynos and the Karanas are mostly unchanged from the time of launch, barring a few new quests that make you visit there.
Now, let's talk about the sound. It's dated, sure, but that little factor hasn't stopped people from loving music before. And EverQuest has some real goldies. Kelethin, the sea approach to Freeport, Rivervale...great music that will stick in your mind forever. It's unfortunate that some of this music, such as the Rivervale theme, are in places you'd never normally visit, but sometimes it's worth it just to hear it.
It's not all rose colored glasses, though: The UI is cluttered beyond belief, to the point you'll be glad you can alter it to your liking. The previously mentioned disjointed graphics can also be rather jarring when you compare newer cash shop aesthetic outfits with older, standard armor. Everything works, but unlike most MMOs these days that are like receiving a new toy with karate chop action, EverQuest is like receiving one of those totally awesome playsets...with the words "Some Assembly Required" etched on the front.
But if you ask me, it's worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994995248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 35765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35028, 'last_played': 1572649923}
review: Great game, with an old-school feel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965108583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1589422809}
review: It's Everquest. There's a reason it's still getting content updates and expansions despite being released in 1999. If you've never played it, but have tried other MMOs that have come out since, you'll probably have difficult time with EQ. It's not exactly user friendly, but the various systems and game mechanics make this game feel closer to a tabletop RPG than an MMO in today's definition/expectation of the genre. The amount of content in this game is nothing short of staggering. So many raids, monsters, items, secrets, spells, skills, races, cities, towns, dungeons, lore and everything else you'd expect from a huge RPG like this. If you end up enjoying it, your patience with the game will go long before you ever even get close to seeing all that this game has to offer. In many people's opinions, this was/is the absolute pinnacle of the MMO genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080800218', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1393217588}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041408471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1256, 'last_played': 1420778353}
review:
A very fun and addicting game. It is older now, and the people who care about graphics won't like it as much. You interact with NPCs through text rather than just clicking which makes it all a little more personal and real seeming to me, but it does take more effort. The price is right for people that like immersive MMO games that let you develop your skills freely as the game progresses. Old school MMOs at its finest.

(Overall 7.5/10, Story 8/10, Gameplay 7/10, Graphics 6/10, Sound 7/10, Replayability 10/10)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995144237', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 9419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8924, 'last_played': 1390418180}
review:
I had many hours of fun on this game. Even when I needed to poo I would hold it in because I didnt want to leave my computer in case someone trained me.

One day I held it in for so long that my feces compacted until its mass was that of a watermelon. My body started to think I was ready to give birth and I began to lactate colostrum. This caused my nipples to become irritated and require a lot of twiddleing and pulling to ease the overwhelming itching sensation, which is why they are so droopy in my picture.

My anus bled for weeks after I had passed brown -but I survived this dark time in my life, all thanks to Everquest.

This game saved my life. Thank you Everquest!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004614427', 'num_games_owned': 1004, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 8394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7723, 'last_played': 1616360909}
review:
Let's begin with the gameplay, it is somewhat repetitive, but it does keep you coming back for more. There are plenty of zones to explore, as well as plenty of mobs to hack to pieces. The graphics designers did a stunning job on the scenery and the architecture, but in terms of character creation, there isn't much variation that makes your character 'unique'. Whether it be the combat music that makes you want to hack up some beasts, or the environmental sounds adding to the overall gamers captivation, the dynamic soundtrack will get you in the mood for anything. 

Have you ever talked to your family, eaten, slept, or bathed? Well that's good, at least you have experienced these things before, because you won't be doing anything but playing EQ once you begin.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962627568', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 940, 'last_played': 1436484849}
review:
Ah, the game that changed my life in so many ways. What can I say about EQ, except that over the 8000+ hours I put into the game during my active period (LoY through TSS expansions on the Vazaelle and Maelin Starpyre servers), I started with nothing, rose to worldwide top of raiding, made lifelong friends, loved, lost, and forever emblazoned in my memory unforgettable experiences which I remember with picture perfection almost a decade later. This game never ceases to invoke a special warm feeling in my heart, that I just can't really get from anything else.

Perhaps the best things about EQ simply the player community, and the enormous world -- especially now that there are 20+ expansions for the game. There's always something awesome to see, whether for the first time or once more for old times' sake. Today's iteration features changes that allow you to revisit a lot of the old world, and new content, by yourself with the help of things like mercenary NPCs, so it's fairly painless to get back into the game, weather for nostalgia or just a change of pace from today's MMOs. You might even run into some people who started at launch in 1999 and are still playing to this day They sure don't make them like this game anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028805789', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 34920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25798, 'last_played': 1681372523}
review: As the years have worn on in Norrath, players tend to stick to themselves, do not invite for grouping and ignore others using 2 or 3 boxing and mercs to accomplish everything ruining what an MMO is about.  TO bad was the best MMO in its prime.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975039363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1792, 'last_played': 1486802218}
review: The original Everquest is still one of the best MMORPGs ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020443956', 'num_games_owned': 4235, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1673126288}
review:
Have been playing EverQuest since 1999, with just a few breaks here and there. Some expansions were great, some were good, and some could have been better - but the entire trip has been well worth it for me :)

The game has a much more challenging risk vs. reward system than never MMOs, which is probably also why the community "matters" more - you can easily ruin your characters name on your play-server, if you act like a total jerk to others... and that will come back and haunt you when you find yourself barred from the guilds that can bring your character forward progression-wise.

With the recent additions of new Progression servers (where you start with the original game enabled only, and then "unlock" expansions in the original order, as time passes) - there has never been a better time for new, as well as old, players to experience EverQuest and all it has to offer :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198052950057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1375120466}

review: So long ago I paid lots of money for a lot of expantions for this game. Spent over two years playing this game. What did i gain from it? Now all those expantions are free and what do you know they have another. They raised the level limit so much its just sad at this point. (was 60 I think when I started playing. Kunrark) Also when you get to higher levels 60+ you can loose a good bit of work in a single death. This doesn't seem like fun to me. The free play is very limited even to someone who paid a lot of money already into this game. Also when I played this like more then 10 years ago I had a different email and there is no way to change your email with out answering a secret question no way I will remember by now. Everything takes large groups of people at some stage and lots of pounding same keys over and over like mindless drones. My advice is run away!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007869345', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1554, 'last_played': 1630298429}
review: I love this game... LOVE it! Most of that comes from my own bias as I played years ago when it first came out, but it is still a fun game, full of things to do, customization, skeletons to manically laugh along with as they float along and die and a generally good time to be had. Unfortunately, most of the community has moved on to bigger and newer games. Though a small portion was revived when the game went free, it's not enough to be a full world breathing exuberance and life as it once was. If you are not coming into the game with a preexisting friend base established and ready to go with you, then I would not recommend it. If you have that though, give it a try and bring on the TRAAAAAAIIIINN!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198107689003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1390066351}
review:
I tried to play this game but I can't. It might have been great with no other competition but ultima online but it doesn't hold up. With the clunky UI and confusing tutorial I don't understand how anyone still plays this game.
Edit: I think people have been interpreting my review the wrong way. The game isn't bad. It just doen't hold up to well and people with nostalgia will really enjoy it but there are so many other free mmos that this isn't really worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027829463', 'num_games_owned': 670, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 22251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19291, 'last_played': 1624189722}
review:
The years have not been kind to Everquest. However it being free to play, my friend and I decided to give it a try. It was extremely painful getting started, but after we got some mentors, and looked up a ton of oudated stuff on the internet, we are stumbling our way through this game.

I would cite my initial reaction with this game as nostalgia. The graphics haven't changed much. While they have improved some old areas and some of the new stuff looks good, it's mostly still old graphics.

However the game is about as fun as it used to be, for me, which is funny, considering how much I used to play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019628627', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 64117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1680103884}
review:
Everquest has defined the Mmo rpg genre long ago-Highly recommended for all PC gamers, new or veterans to mmo's and for many epic reasons. The Free to Play system is fair in terms of what you might spend on other FTP games. Buying the latetest expansion of Everquest grants you all previous 19 expansions also. The game is massive in content. The players are extremely loyal and helpful too.  Factor about Everquest that is apart from many many modern mmo's is that EQ was built/designed around the round table of -in my own words ~grouping with players to advance. Sense 99 there are thousands of tales from players including myself of reminiscing the 'glory days' of eq.
Bottom Line- FTP is a honest and fair deal if you decide to pay-Subscriptions and content is also very generous and affordable
Countless roads to venture in the world
EQ Unique AA system for classes sinks every mmo's 'talent choices' for classes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015247874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 126073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102139, 'last_played': 1399771121}
review:
Free-to-play with upgrade options ( Silver and Gold accounts ), Everquest still has population on many of its servers. Content up to VoA ( Veil of Alaris ) can be accessed for free, and characters can obtain up to level 95 ( without gold or purchase of the latest expansion ). It's never been easier to pick up, and catch up.

Whether returning for nostalgia, or coming into the game for the first time, Everquest still has something to offer. There are plenty of guilds available, group and raid content, and solo opportunities for any class you're willing to invest in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116596283', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1386318977}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045381877', 'num_games_owned': 557, 'num_reviews': 2587, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1414476439}
review:
I came back to try Everquest again, after so long a lot was different, but a lot was still nostalgic. I will leave you with my review.

Released in 1999 Everquest is a hugely influential MMO, Influencing the genre even to this day. I am not as naive as to say that Everquest Started the MMO craze. I can say however that it most definitely helped get it off the ground. The game is still going strong with around 20 expansions to date. I have got to say if you want that classic feel in an mmo come on back to Everquest. Its still here, and still strong!

I may prefer Everquest 2 more, but I think its great that the game is still open for those hard core Everquest 1 fans, and new people interested in the game alike.


EDIT: My previous review I just noticed looked as if I typed it drunk. so I completely replaced it with this review.

review: The first MMO I ever played and definitely still one of the best ones out there. Yea the graphics are out-dated but what do you want? This game is old enough to be in High School and it's still an amazing game and definitely worth playing. Looking at all of the features this game has it's just amazing that even over a decade ago this game was at the forefront of it's genre. Shit it was the ONLY online game anyone played until WoW came along pretty much. And honestly I'd rather play EQ than WoW any day. Now that it's free (and not pay to win) I hope that more people get to enjoy this amazing game like I did for so many years - and will continue to enjoy for many more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198070585607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 110740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37966, 'last_played': 1673519757}
review:
With 19 expansions EverQuest really does live up to being a MASSIVELY multiplayer online RPG... some might just say it's bloated.
The graphics may not be much chop these days but the gameplay is still challenging, although not as unforgiving as the original and the first couple of expansions. It requires a fair amount of 'dedication' to develop your characters making its successors in games like World of Warcraft seem like MMO easy-mode.
I probably like this more for nostalgic fun reasons rather than it being cutting edge, but it's a good way to kill some time and it's 'free-to-play' afterall. The free-to-play version gives you two character slots and a limited range of races/classes.
I have a char on the Povar-Quellious server - a druid called Seeate.

Although for the authentic EQ experience, I'd recommend Project 1999, an exceptional EQ emulator. Google it :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197986511953', 'num_games_owned': 781, 'num_reviews': 311, 'playtime_forever': 3, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1410593392}
review:
It's fucking Everquest.

One of the old as shit MMORPGs that's been around for more then 10 years. 

It's funny though. One of the things Everquest was known for was controvercy. Like it had a black market auction house where people would trade rare items for hundreds of dollars. Today, almost every MMORPG has an ingame store. Or in Blizzard's case, a legalized auction house where they take a cut of the profits.

You gotta love innovation. One step forward, two steps back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003013188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 0, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 0}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971850954', 'num_games_owned': 1540, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 31992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3995, 'last_played': 1711223477}
review:
long ago was a fun game. but ruined by countless expansions, and flooding of worthless rude players. Def not recommended anymore :(

Edit:Came back for progression servers, which are really nice ngl.. BUUUT the player base is still modernly toxic af.. Kill theft, camp raiding, and just general rudeness abound. Way to many politics in general world chats etc...
Bots and Boxers still roam rampant in ways that show either bot farms or basement dwellers have actively overthrown the world of Norrath.

If you can ignore all that, it is *mostly* the nice game it once was but with faster XP and other Quality of Life Improvements at the start on the Yelinak server.
Still gets a negative review tho, because where it was once an open and very nice community of players, its been turned into a similar waste dump of the CoD generation. :(
Where once Kill Stealers and camp raiders would've been blasted and black listed on server forums and thus ostracized from the community, now they're a blatant part of it. Unpunished and something that has to be dealt with since GM's clearly don't exist (or the world chats wouldn't be so full of such toxicity),  and DB doesn't give one flying F so long as they're getting money.

This isn't your fathers, mothers, or grandparents game anymore. It's a cesspool with a small wading area thats fine to swim in, but still full of pi**

author: {'steamid': '76561197982412558', 'num_games_owned': 1251, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 80652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1708224172}
review: This is where I got my MMO start. The wonderful times I had with this game. Exploring a unknown world filled with danger and excitement. Finding uncountable riches and treasure. This game drew you in and never let go. I highly recommend this game. The learning curve has changed and more friendly than when I started. If you want a fantasy game with rich lore and beautiful sights. There is no better place than Norrath.
